Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] |caps1 = 73 |goals1 = 33 | years2 = 2011–2014 |clubs2 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |caps2 = 10 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2012–2013 |clubs3 = → [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion ]] (loan) |caps3 = 35 |goals3 = 17 | years4 = 2013–2014 |clubs4 = → [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] (loan) |caps4 = 31 |goals4 = 15 | years5 = 2014–2017 |clubs5 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] |caps5 = 110 |goals5 = 53 | years6 = 2017– |clubs6 = [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] |caps6 = 61 |goals6 = 28<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | nationalyears1 = 2008 |nationalteam1 = Belgium U15 |nationalcaps1 = 4 |nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2011 |nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national under-18 football team|Belgium U18]] |nationalcaps2 = 1 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2009 |nationalteam3 = [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]] |nationalcaps3 = 5 |nationalgoals3 = 1 | nationalyears4 = 2010– |nationalteam4 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] |nationalcaps4 = 79 |nationalgoals4 = 45<!-- Three of his matches with the Belgium national football team are not official according to FIFA rules. --> | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Association football|football]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{fb|BEL}}}} {{Medal|Comp|[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|3rd|[[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 Russia]]|}} | club-update = 18:46, 10 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 16 October 2018 }} '''Romelu Menama Lukaku Bolingoli''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈroːmeːlu luˈkaːku}}; born 13 May 1993) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for English club [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]].
Born in [[Antwerp]], Lukaku began his professional career at [[Belgian First Division A|Belgian Pro League]] club [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] in 2009, where he made his senior debut, at age 16. In his first season, he completed the campaign as the league's top goalscorer, and won the league championship. Following similar individual success in his second season, highlighted by his win of the [[Belgian Ebony Shoe]], Lukaku relocated to England to transfer to [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2011, for a fee of £10 million (€12 million).
Lukaku featured sparingly in his first campaign at Chelsea, and instead, he decided to depart on loan at fellow league club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in 2012. Lukaku shone with the team, registering 17 league goals, and guided the club to an unlikely eighth-place finish. However, after no further reassurances over playing time, he again departed on loan, this time to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], in 2013. After finishing the season with 15 league goals and helping Everton reach a club-record points tally, he joined the team in a permanent deal worth a club-record fee of £28 million in 2014.
After three successful individual campaigns on Merseyside, which included an appearance in the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Premier League 8|2016–17]] [[PFA Team of the Year]], Lukaku signed for Manchester United in 2017, for an initial fee of £75 million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Romelu Lukaku completes Manchester United move in deal that could reach world record £90m |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/07/10/romelu-lukaku-completes-75m-manchester-united-move/ |work=The Telegraph |date=19 June 2018}}</ref> This transfer made him the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|most expensive Belgian player of all time]].
A Belgian international, Lukaku has played 79 games for his country, and registered 45 goals, making him [[Belgium national football team records and statistics#General 2|Belgium's all-time top goalscorer]].{{Cref2|N1}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.live.sporza.be/cm/lmc.mobile/m_mc_voetbal/oefeninterlands/1.3087128|title=Duivels winnen geen zieltjes met krappe oefenzege, Lukaku topschutter aller tijden|website=m.live.sporza.be}}</ref> Lukaku made his senior international debut for Belgium in 2010, at age 17, and has since represented his country at three major tournaments, including two [[FIFA World Cup]]s and one [[UEFA Euro 2016|UEFA European Championship]]. At the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]], Lukaku led Belgium to a third place finish by finishing as the joint second-highest goalscorer, and won the Bronze Boot.
==Club career== ===Early career=== Lukaku joined his local team [[K. Rupel Boom F.C.|Rupel Boom]] at age five. After four seasons at Rupel Boom, Lukaku was discovered by scouts of [[Lierse S.K.|Lierse]], a [[Belgian First Division A|Belgian Pro League]] club with an established youth academy. He played for Lierse from 2004 until 2006, scoring 121 goals in 68 matches.<ref name=LukakuYouth>{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2011/01/17/2309143/romelu-lukaku-the-full-interview-teenage-sensation-reveals |title=The Full Interview: Teenage Sensation Reveals All About His Life, Loves And His Footballing 'Gift From God' |publisher=Goal.com |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=20 January 2011}}</ref> After Lierse were relegated from the Belgian Pro League, [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] purchased 13 youth players from Lierse in the 2006 mid-season, including Lukaku. He played three more years as a youth player with Anderlecht, scoring 131 goals in 93 matches.
===Anderlecht=== When Lukaku turned 16 on 13 May 2009, he signed a professional contract with Anderlecht lasting until 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=43883 |title=Lukaku : " Je sais que je serai récompensé de mes efforts " |publisher=FootGoal.net |date=2 September 2009 |accessdate=17 November 2010 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903180212/http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=43883 |archivedate=3 September 2009 }}</ref> Eleven days later, he made his Belgian First Division debut on 24 May 2009 in the [[2008–09 Belgian First Division#Championship playoff|championship play-off]] match against [[Standard Liège]] as a 69th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Defender (association football)|defender]] [[Víctor Bernárdez]].<ref name=StandardBelgi>{{cite news| title = Standard is opnieuw kampioen van België| url = http://www.sporza.be/cm/sporza/voetbal/Jupiler_Pro_League/2.5503/MF_090524_STA_AND| publisher = Sporza| date = 24 May 2009| accessdate = 26 May 2009| language = Dutch }}</ref> Anderlecht lost the match 1–0. Lukaku became a regular member of Anderlecht's first team during the [[2009–10 R.S.C. Anderlecht season|2009–10 season]], scoring his first goal at senior level against [[S.V. Zulte Waregem|Zulte Waregem]] in the 89th minute after coming on as substitute for [[Rubenilson dos Santos da Rocha|Kanu]] on 28 August 2009. "After scoring I dived into a sea of happiness," he told Berend Scholten from UEFA.com. "You think you are flying and can take on the whole world."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=1457433.html|title=Lukaku fast-tracked to the top|date=2 March 2010|accessdate=6 March 2010|work=Berend Scholten, UEFA.com}}</ref> He ended the season as the top goalscorer in the [[2009–10 Belgian Pro League|Pro League]] with 15 goals as Anderlecht won its 30th [[List of Belgian football champions|Belgian title]].<ref name=punches>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2010/apr/01/romelu-lukaku-anderlecht|title=Anderlecht's Romelu Lukaku punches his weight and some – aged only 16|date=2 April 2010|accessdate=13 April 2014|work=The Guardian}}</ref> He also scored four goals during the club's run to the last 16 of the [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League]].<ref name=punches/> During the [[2010–11 Belgian Pro League|2010–11 season]], Lukaku scored 20 goals in all competitions, but Anderlecht failed to retain their league title despite finishing top of the table during the regular season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2011/08/28/2640475/chelsea-striker-romelu-lukaku-dreams-of-playing-alongside|title=Chelsea striker Romelu Lukaku dreams of playing alongside his brother Jordan|date=28 August 2011|accessdate=13 April 2014|work=Goal.com}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== [[File:Romelu Lukaku Chelsea vs AS-Roma 10AUG2013.jpg|thumb|140px|upright|left|Lukaku warming up for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2013]]
In August 2011, Lukaku joined [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for a fee reported to be around €12 million (£10 million), rising to €20 million (£17 million) in add-ons. Lukaku was given the number 18 shirt and signed a five-year contract.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/sportwereld/cnt/DC3DOMDV|title=Chelsea betaalt 12 miljoen voor Lukaku (maar het kan oplopen tot 20 miljoen)|publisher=Sportwereld|date=12 August 2011}}</ref> He made his home debut in a 3–1 victory over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the 83rd minute, coming on as a substitute for [[Fernando Torres]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14600575.stm |title=Chelsea 3–1 Norwich|publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 August 2011 |accessdate=29 December 2011}}</ref>
Lukaku made his first start for the club in the [[2011–12 Football League Cup|League Cup]] against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. Chelsea went on to win the match on [[penalty shootout|penalties]]. He spent the majority of the season playing for the [[Chelsea F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserves]] and started his first Premier League match on 13 May 2012, , against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], and turned in a [[man of the match]] performance, providing an [[Assist (football)|assist]] for [[John Terry]]'s opener.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/chelsea-cruise-against-blackburn-rovers-ahead-of-champions-league-final-in-munich-7743453.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Nick | last=Szczepanik | date=14 May 2012 | title=Chelsea cruise against Blackburn Rovers ahead of Champions League final in Munich}}</ref> However, Lukaku stressed he was disappointed with his involvement at the end of his debut season, revealing that, after his side's [[UEFA Champions League]] win in [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|the final]] on 19 May, he refused to hold the trophy as he did not feel like a winner.<ref>{{cite news|title=Romelu Lukaku felt no joy at Chelsea's Champions League win|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18284627|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 May 2012|accessdate=24 August 2012}}</ref>
====West Bromwich Albion (loan)==== [[File:Romelu Lukaku kick off Fulham v WBA (cropped).jpg|thumb|140px|upright|Lukaku playing for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in 2012]]
After speculation linking Lukaku to a loan move to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham in talks to loan Lukaku from rivals Chelsea|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2012/07/17/3245447/fulham-in-talks-to-loan-lukaku-from-rivals-chelsea|publisher=Goal.com|date=17 July 2012|accessdate=24 August 2012}}</ref> on 10 August 2012, he joined [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on a season-long loan deal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10268~2877749,00.html |title=LUKAKU WEST BROM LOAN |publisher=chelseafc.com |date=10 August 2012 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120811235319/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10268~2877749,00.html |archivedate=11 August 2012 }}</ref> He scored his first league goal eight days later, coming on as a substitute in the 77th minute in a 3–0 win against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19221306 |title=West Brom 3–0 Liverpool |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2012 |accessdate=3 September 2013 |first=Phil |last=McNulty}}</ref> He made his full debut in a win against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] at [[The Hawthorns]], scoring the match's only goal.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19614964 "West Brom 1–0 Reading"] BBC Sport. 22 September 2012. Retrieved 14 January 2013.</ref> On 24 November, Lukaku came on as a 70th-minute substitute for [[Shane Long]] and netted a penalty and provided an assist to [[Marc-Antoine Fortuné]], as West Brom defeated [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 4–2 away at the [[Stadium of Light]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2237783/Sunderland-2-West-Brom-4-match-report-Zoltan-Gera-Shane-Long-Romelu-Lukaku-Marc-Antoine-Fortune-score.html |title=Sunderland 2 West Brom 4: Albion rewrite the history books as they go up to third |publisher=Daily Mail |date=24 November 2012 }}</ref> The win proved to be West Brom's fourth consecutive win in the top flight for the first time since 1980.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20374862 |title=West Brom went third in the Premier League after recording four successive top-flight wins for the first time since 1980 with victory at Sunderland. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2012 |accessdate=5 February 2013 }}</ref> On 12 January 2013, Lukaku had his first multi-goal game in the Premier League, giving West Brom a 0–2 lead against Reading, before a late comeback gave the Berkshire club a 3–2 victory at the [[Madejski Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=345848&cc=5901 |title=Reading 3–2 West Bromwich Albion |publisher=ESPNFC |date=12 January 2013 }}</ref> In the face of claims he wanted to stay with West Brom for another year, asserted by the ''[[Daily Mail]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2261823/Romelu-Lukaku-wants-stay-West-Brom.html#axzz2K4M51IFV |title=I don't care what Chelsea are doing at the moment: Lukaku wants to stay at West Brom |publisher=Daily Mail |date=14 January 2013 }}</ref> Lukaku confirmed to the press he still wished to become a legend at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11661/8474316/Romelu-Lukaku-believes-he-can-become-a-legend-at-Chelsea |title=Romelu Lukaku believes he can become a legend at Chelsea |publisher=Sky Sports |date=5 February 2013 }}</ref> On 11 February, Lukaku came on as a substitute and scored his tenth Premier League goal of the season against Liverpool in a match that ended 2–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21318809 |title=Gareth McAuley and Romelu Lukaku scored late goals as West Brom pinched a remarkable victory at Liverpool to end a sequence of six games without a win. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 February 2013 }}</ref>
He scored his second brace of the campaign, scoring both goals for West Brom in their 2–1 home defeat of Sunderland on 23 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2283299/West-Brom-2-Sunderland-1--match-report-Romelu-Lukaku-strikes-twice.html |title=West Brom 2 Sunderland 1: Lukaku at the double as Baggies ease past Black Cats |publisher=Daily Mail |date=23 February 2013 }}</ref> On 9 March, in a league match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], Lukaku scored the equalising goal before having a penalty kick saved; West Brom eventually won the game courtesy of a [[Jonathan de Guzmán]] own goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21639482 |title=Romelu Lukaku continued his good form as West Brom beat Swansea to move up to seventh in the Premier League. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 March 2013 }}</ref> On 19 May, coming on as a second-half substitute, Lukaku scored a remarkable second-half [[perfect hat-trick|perfect]] [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|hat-trick]], as West Brom came from three goals down to draw 5–5 in the season's final home match against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2326929/West-Brom-5-Manchester-United-5-Sir-Alex-Fergusons-match-goal-thriller.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title=West Brom 5 Manchester United 5: Fergie's career ends with ten-goal thriller |publisher=Daily Mail |date=19 May 2013 |accessdate=19 May 2013 }}</ref> The match was [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]]'s 1,500th and last match in charge of United, and the highest-scoring draw in the history of the [[Premier League records and statistics|Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/may/19/west-bromwich-albion-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report |title=Manchester United share 10 goals with West Brom in Alex Ferguson's finale |publisher=The Guardian |date=19 May 2013 |accessdate=19 May 2013 }}</ref> Despite being loaned out by the club, Lukaku outscored all of his Chelsea teammates in the Premier League that season, being the sixth-highest goal scorer of the [[2012–13 Premier League|2012–13 season]] with 17 goals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/01/18/will-romelu-lukaku-come-back-to-haunt-west-bromwich-albion-4267677/|title=Will Romelu Lukaku come back to haunt West Bromwich Albion?|date=18 January 2014|accessdate=4 August 2014|publisher=Metro}}</ref> Lukaku played two Premier League matches for Chelsea at the beginning of the [[2013–14 Chelsea F.C. season|2013–14 season]]. He also came on as a substitute in the [[2013 UEFA Super Cup]], ultimately missing the deciding penalty in the shootout as [[Manuel Neuer]] saved his shot and Chelsea lost to [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefasupercup/history/season=2013/|title=UEFA Super Cup - 2013: Neuer puts an end to Chelsea hopes|last=UEFA.com|website=UEFA.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-30}}</ref>
===Everton=== ====2013–14 season (loan)==== [[File:Romelu Lukaku 2014-05-03.jpg|thumb|upright|Lukaku pre-match with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in 2014]]
On the final day of the summer 2013 transfer window, Lukaku joined [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11671/8903847/transfer-deadline-day-everton-sign-james-mccarthy-and-romelu-lukaku |title=Transfer deadline day: Everton sign James McCarthy and Romelu Lukaku, Lukaku scored on his debut after replacing Steven Naismith at half time. |publisher=BSkyB |work=Sky Sports |date=3 September 2013 |accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> The striker made his début for the Toffees away to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 21 September 2013, scoring the winning goal in a 3–2 victory for Everton. During the header, he had a collision with a West Ham defender and was taken off the pitch for some treatment. The physio had to tell him he had scored the winner.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24089772|title=West Ham 2–3 Everton|date=21 September 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He scored twice on his home debut nine days later in a 3–2 win against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], as well assisting [[Ross Barkley]]'s goal.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24201002 "Everton 3–2 Newcastle"] BBC Sport. 30 September 2013. Retrieved 7 October 2013.</ref> He then opened the scoring in a 3–1 defeat to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in the following match.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24350210 "Manchester City 3–1 Everton"] BBC Sport. 5 October 2013. Retrieved 7 October 2013.</ref> He continued his impressive start at the club by netting the opening goal in a 2–0 win over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], and then scored twice in the first [[Merseyside derby]] of the season as Everton drew 3–3 against Liverpool, with Lukaku stating afterwards it was the best experience he has had in his short career.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24591399 | title=Aston Villa 0–2 Everton | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11671/9043000/romelu-lukaku-claims-evertons-draw-with-liverpool-is-the-best-derby-he-has-played-in | title=Romelu Lukaku claims Everton's draw with Liverpool is the 'best derby' he has played in | publisher=[[Sky Sports]] | accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>
In January 2014, Lukaku was named by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as one of the ten most promising young players in Europe,<ref name="top10list">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/jan/19/next-10-big-things-europes-top-youngsters|title=The next 10 big things: Europe's top youngsters and stars of the future|date=18 January 2014|work=The Guardian}}</ref> but later in the month was taken off on a stretcher with an ankle ligament damage after [[Gareth Barry]] slipped and slid into the striker as he attempted to block [[Steven Gerrard]]'s opening goal in the Merseyside derby against Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25822244 | title=Romelu Lukaku: Everton striker out for 'weeks rather than months' | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25822244 | title=Liverpool 4–0 Everton | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | accessdate=29 January 2014}}</ref> Lukaku made his return from injury against West Ham in March 2014, scoring the only goal of the match on the 81st minute after coming on as a second-half substitute.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26300994 | title=Everton 1–0 West Ham | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | accessdate=1 March 2014}}</ref> On 6 April, he scored one goal and assisted another as Everton beat [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 3–0 at [[Goodison Park]] to record a sixth consecutive Premier League win.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26807037|title=Everton 3–0 Arsenal|date=6 April 2014|accessdate=13 April 2014|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> His final goal for the loan period came on the last day of the season as he scored the second in a 2–0 win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27273312 | title=Hull City 0–2 Everton | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> Lukaku found the net 15 times in 31 league matches to help Everton to fifth place with a club record of 72 Premier League points.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2014/05/14/magic-numbers-roberto-s-record-breakers | title=Magic Numbers: Roberto's Record-Breakers | publisher=[[Everton F.C.]] | accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref>
====2014–16==== [[File:Romelu Lukaku vs Dinamo Kyiv (16869431132) (cropped).jpg|thumb|180px|left|Lukaku playing for Everton in 2015]]
Lukaku had signed a five-year deal with Everton in July 2014, for a club record fee of £28 million, and he was assigned the number 10 shirt.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/28569197|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 June 2017|date=30 July 2014|title=Romelu Lukaku: Everton sign Chelsea striker}}</ref> He scored his first goal as a permanent player on 13 September, against his former club West Brom. Lukaku [[Goal celebration#Notable non-celebrations|did not celebrate the goal]], and was applauded by the West Brom fans for his sign of respect. On 19 February 2015, Lukaku scored his first Everton hat-trick in a 4–1 win for Everton against [[BSC Young Boys]] in the [[UEFA Europa League]] last 32; he struck with a header, a right-foot shot and a left-foot shot.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31523676|title=BSC Young Boys 1–4 Everton|date=30 July 2014|accessdate=30 July 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He added another two goals in a 3–1 win in the second leg a week later.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=Ian|title=Everton 3–1 BSC Young Boys|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31627528|accessdate=27 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=26 February 2015}}</ref> With eight goals, he was the tournament's joint highest scorer that season, alongside [[Alan Carvalho|Alan]] of [[FC Red Bull Salzburg|red Bull Salzburg]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Alan and Everton's Lukaku finish as top scorers|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=2249783.html|accessdate=27 May 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=27 May 2015}}</ref>
In the second game of the [[2015–16 Premier League]] season, Lukaku scored a first-half double in Everton's 0–3 win at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 15 August 2015 with his first two shots on target. Before the match, he presented a T-shirt to a home fan whom he had accidentally struck with the ball during shooting practice.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Aimee|title=Southampton 0–3 Everton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33832170|accessdate=16 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2015}}</ref> On 26 August, he scored another brace in a 5–3 extra-time win over [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] in the [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC Sport – Barnsley 3–5 Everton (AET) |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33969808 |date=26 August 2015 |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> On 28 September, Lukaku scored twice and assisted the other against West Brom as he managed to guide his team from losing 2–0 to winning 2–3.<ref>{{cite news|title=West Brom 2–3 Everton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34311167|accessdate=4 October 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 September 2015}}</ref> He scored against Liverpool the following week in a 1–1 draw at Goodison Park.<ref>{{cite news|title=Everton 2–3 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34372497|accessdate=4 October 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 October 2015}}</ref> On 21 November, Lukaku scored twice in a 4–0 win over Aston Villa, becoming the fifth player under 23 years of age to score at least 50 Premier League goals, after [[Robbie Fowler]], [[Michael Owen]], [[Wayne Rooney]] and [[Cristiano Ronaldo]].<ref name="becomes">{{cite news|title=Romelu Lukaku becomes fourth-youngest player to score 50 goals before turning 23 in Premier League history|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3328456/Romelu-Lukaku-joins-Cristiano-Ronaldo-Wayne-Rooney-50-Premier-League-goals-turning-23.html|accessdate=22 November 2015|work=Daily Mail|date=21 November 2015}}</ref> On 7 December, Lukaku scored a close-range goal in a 1–1 draw against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], his 50th in 100 appearances in all competitions for Everton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/everton-vs-c-palace/341329|title=Everton 1–1 Crystal Palace: Romelu Lukaku secures point for hosts|publisher=}}</ref> On 12 December, Lukaku became the first Everton player to score in six consecutive Premier League matches, and the first to score in seven consecutive matches in all competitions since [[Bob Latchford]] 40 years previously, when he opened the scoring in the ''Toffees''' 1–1 draw with Norwich City at [[Carrow Road]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/sport/can-romelu-lukaku-break-jamie-vardys-premier-league-goalscoring-record-711126.html|title=Can Romelu Lukaku break Jamie Vardy's Premier League goalscoring record?|date=12 December 2015|work=The Irish Examiner}}</ref> In his next match, a 3–2 defeat to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], Lukaku became the first Everton player since [[Dave Hickson]] in 1954 to score in eight consecutive matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2015/12/19/gc-evertons-romelu-lukaku-breaks-a-61-year-record-after-goal-aga/|title=Everton's Romelu Lukaku breaks a 61-year record after goal against Leicester|first=Graham|last=Corking|publisher=}}</ref>
On 6 February 2016, Lukaku scored his 20th goal of the season in a 0–3 victory at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], meaning he was the first Everton player since [[Graeme Sharp]] to score at least 20 goals in all competitions in consecutive seasons for Everton. The strike was also his 16th league goal of the season, equalling Premier League goal scoring records for Everton set by [[Tony Cottee]] and [[Andrei Kanchelskis]] in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsno.co.uk/everton-news/2016/02/record-breaking-lukaku-happy-to-help-team/|title=Record-breaking Lukaku happy to help team – NSNO|publisher=}}</ref> Lukaku followed this goal with another strike in a 0–2 victory at [[AFC Bournemouth]]'s [[Dean Court]] for his 21st goal of the season. This victory sent Everton into the quarter-finals of the [[2015–16 FA Cup|FA Cup]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35566556|title=Bournemouth 0–2 Everton|date=20 February 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and equalled the number of goals scored in all competitions by [[Yakubu (footballer)|Yakubu]] for Everton in the [[2007–08 Everton F.C. season|2007–08 season]], the previous best in the Premier League era.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/players/y/ya/yakubu-ayegbeni|title=Yakubu Ayegbeni – Everton Football Club|publisher=}}</ref> On 1 March, Lukaku scored in a 1–3 victory against Aston Villa at [[Villa Park]], his 17th league goal of the season, a Premier League-era record for Everton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/aston-villa-1-3-everton-10955746|title=Aston Villa 1–3 Everton full-time report: Blues go into top half after cruise|first=Phil|last=Kirkbride|date=1 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref> The goal also meant Lukaku had equalled his previous best goal return in a league season, set during his loan spell at West Brom in the 2012–13 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=56521|title=Romelu Lukaku – Football Stats – Everton – Age 23 – Soccer Base|publisher=}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== [[File:Manchester United v Everton, April 2017 (06).JPG|thumb|right|Lukaku with Everton in 2017]]
On 12 September 2016, Lukaku scored his first goals of the [[2016–17 Everton F.C. season|2016–17 season]] with all three goals in a 3–0 against Sunderland at the Stadium of Light. His goals were scored in 11 minutes and 37 seconds, making it the 12th-fastest hat-trick in Premier League history.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37273038 |title=Sunderland 0–3 Everton |date=10 September 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 4 February 2017, Lukaku scored four goals, the first of which was Everton's fastest ever Premier League goal, against Bournemouth in a 6–3 victory at Goodison Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/02/04/everton-6-bournemouth-3romelu-lukaku-scores-toffees-fastest/|title=Everton 6 Bournemouth 3: Romelu Lukaku scores Toffees' fastest Premier League goal in Goodison rout |date=4 February 2017 |publisher=The Telegraph}}</ref> It was also the 300th hat-trick scored in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/02/07/revealed-20-premier-league-teams-have-scored-hat-tricks-history/|title=Revealed: The 20 Premier League teams who have scored most hat-tricks in history of competition|date=7 February 2017 |publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref> On 25 February 2017, he equalled [[Duncan Ferguson]]'s [[List of Everton F.C. records and statistics|club record]] for Premier League goals, scoring his 60th EPL goal for the Toffees in a 2–0 victory over Sunderland at Goodison Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/everton-vs-sland/356587|title=Everton 2–0 Sunderland: Romelu Lukaku equals club record in win |date=25 February 2017 |publisher=Skysports.com}}</ref> On 5 March, he surpassed Ferguson to become the outright record holder, scoring in a 3–2 loss against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] away at [[White Hart Lane]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/romelu-lukaku-evertons-can-you-12706546|title=ROMELU LUKAKU: EVERTON'S LEADING PREMIER LEAGUE GOALSCORER|date=7 March 2017|work=Liverpool Echo}}</ref> In the next match, a 3–0 home win against West Brom, Lukaku scored to become the first Everton player since Bob Latchford to score 20 or more goals in all competitions for three consecutive seasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EFC_Statto/status/840604310773858304|title=EFC Statto on Twitter|publisher=}}</ref> A week later, during a 4–0 victory over Hull City, he scored twice to take his league goals tally to 21 for the season, thereby becoming the first Everton player since [[Gary Lineker]] 31 years previously to surpass 20 league goals in a season, as well as being the fourth player and first foreign player to score 80 Premier League goals before the age of 24.<ref name=eighty>{{cite news|last1=Hafeez|first1=Shamoon|title=Premier League statistics: Arsenal, Mahrez, Vardy, Lukaku, Deeney|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39318111|accessdate=21 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 March 2017}}</ref>
In March 2017, Lukaku turned down a new five-year contract worth a reported £140,000 a week amidst rumours of a return to Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Romelu Lukaku: Everton striker rejects new contract at Goodison Park|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39273691|accessdate=21 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 March 2017}}</ref> In an interview, he questioned the club's ambition to make big transfers and chase Champions League qualification, offending his manager [[Ronald Koeman]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Romelu Lukaku must respect Everton contract – Ronald Koeman|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39295524|accessdate=21 March 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 March 2017}}</ref> A goal in a 3–1 win for Everton against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 15 April meant Lukaku was the first Everton player since Bob Latchford to score 25 goals in two consecutive seasons in all competitions, and the first player since the legendary [[Dixie Dean]] to score in nine consecutive matches at Goodison Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/romelu-lukaku-stunning-stats-everton-12899448|title=How Lukaku has made history in stunning Everton season|first=Paul|last=Gorst|date=15 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> On 20 April 2017, Lukaku was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]] for the first time.<ref name=PFA1617>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39648483 |title=PFA teams of the year: Chelsea and Tottenham dominate Premier League XI |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 April 2017 |accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref> He was also included in the six player shortlists for the [[PFA Player of the Year]] and [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] awards.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thepfa.com/news/2017/4/13/pfa-mens-players-player-of-the-year|title=Men's PFA Players' Player of the Year 2017|date=13 April 2017|work=The Professional Footballers Association}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thepfa.com/news/2017/4/13/pfa-mens-young-player-of-the-year|title=Men's PFA Young Player of the Year 2017|date=13 April 2017|work=The Professional Footballers Association}}</ref>
===Manchester United=== [[File:Romelu Lukaku 27 September 2017 cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Lukaku playing for Manchester United in the UEFA Champions League in 2017]]
Lukaku joined Manchester United on 10 July 2017, signing a five-year contract with the option of a further year.<ref>{{cite news |title=United sign Romelu Lukaku |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2017/Jul/club-statement-manchester-united-confirm-romelu-lukaku-has-joined-the-club-from-everton.aspx |website=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=10 July 2017 }}</ref> Although the fee was officially undisclosed, it was reported to be worth an initial £75 million, plus £15 million in add-ons.<ref>{{cite news |title=Romelu Lukaku: Man Utd sign Everton striker for initial £75m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40550934 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=10 July 2017 }}</ref> Lukaku's signing came a day after former Manchester United captain [[Wayne Rooney]] left the club to return to Everton, Rooney's boyhood club.<ref>{{cite news |title=Rooney to join Everton |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2017/Jul/wayne-rooney-is-to-rejoin-everton-from-manchester-united.aspx |website=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=10 July 2017 }}</ref> Ahead of the [[2017–18 Manchester United F.C. season|2017–18 season]], Lukaku asked the permission of [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] if he could take over the number 9 shirt from him.<ref>{{cite news |first=Rob |last=Dawson |title=Romelu Lukaku to wear No. 9 shirt at United with Ibrahimovic's permission |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/story/3155654/romelu-lukaku-to-wear-no-9-shirt-at-united-with-zlatan-ibrahimovics-permission |work=ESPN FC |publisher=ESPN Sports Media |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=15 July 2017 }}</ref> Lukaku was confirmed to have been given the number on 14 July.<ref>{{cite news |first=James |last=Tuck |title=Lindelof and Lukaku shirt numbers revealed |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2017/Jul/Victor-Lindelof-Romelu-Lukaku-Manchester-United-shirt-numbers-revealed.aspx |website=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=15 July 2017 }}</ref>
He made his debut against [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] on 8 August in the [[2017 UEFA Super Cup]], and scored his first competitive goal for the club in a 2–1 defeat.<ref>{{cite news |title= Real Beat Man Utd in Super Cup |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40788621 |publisher= BBC Sport |date=8 August 2017 |accessdate=13 August 2017}}</ref> His league debut came five days later at home to West Ham. Lukaku scored twice in a 4–0 win,<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United 4–0 West Ham United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40841358 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2017 |accessdate=13 August 2017}}</ref> becoming the fourth Manchester United player to score two goals on his Premier League debut for the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/452144|title=Lukaku joins exclusive club with debut double|publisher=Premier League|date=14 August 2017|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> On 17 September, Lukaku scored United's third goal in a 4–0 win over his former club Everton, with Lukaku running over towards Everton fans and cupping his ears during his [[goal celebration]] in response to being booed throughout the game.<ref>{{cite news |title=Everton fans unhappy with Romelu Lukaku's goal celebration |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-fans-unhappy-romelu-lukakus-13634711 |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=Liverpool Echo}}</ref> On 27 September, Lukaku scored twice in a 4–1 [[UEFA Champions League]] win over [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], taking his tally to 10 goals in his first nine appearances. In doing so, he broke the record set by [[Bobby Charlton|Sir Bobby Charlton]] who had scored nine goals in his first nine appearances for the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11667/11056777/jose-mourinho-says-romelu-lukakus-form-amazing-but-man-utd-team-mates-deserve-credit-too|title=Jose Mourinho says Romelu Lukaku's form amazing but Man Utd team-mates deserve credit too|website=Sky Sports|date=28 September 2017|accessdate=29 September 2017}}</ref> In a 2–1 win over his former club Chelsea on 25 February 2018, Lukaku scored the equaliser and then assisted [[Jesse Lingard]]'s game-winning goal.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oscroft|first1=Tim|title=Manchester United 2–1 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43101688|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=16 March 2018|date=25 February 2018}}</ref> He scored his 200th goal for club and country on 13 March in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] that eliminated Manchester United from the Champions League in the round of 16.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rodger|first1=James|title=Romelu Lukaku reacts to scoring his 200th goal as Manchester United exit Champions League|url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/romelu-lukaku-reacts-scoring-200th-14408325|website=[[Birmingham Mail]]|accessdate=16 March 2018|date=14 March 2018}}</ref> On 31 March 2018, Lukaku scored to open a 2–0 home win over Swansea. It was his [[List of Premier League players with 100 or more goals|100th Premier League goal]] in his 216th game, and made him the fifth youngest of the 28 players to reach the tally.<ref name=sky100>{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Nick|title=Romelu Lukaku's 100 Premier League goals in stats|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11667/11311506/romelu-lukakus-100-premier-league-goals-in-stats|accessdate=31 March 2018|publisher=Sky Sports|date=31 March 2018}}</ref>
Lukaku started the 2018–19 season with four goals in his first five appearances, including a brace against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], before a 12-game drought lasting from 19 September to 27 November 2018. Goals against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] followed before the sacking of manager [[José Mourinho]], only for Mourinho's replacement – former United striker [[Ole Gunnar Solskjær]] – to leave Lukaku out of the squad entirely for his first two games in charge against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] and [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]]. Lukaku made substitute appearances in United's next two games against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]<ref>{{cite news |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |title=Man Utd 4-1 Bournemouth: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer says he is not purely focused on attack |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46663363 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 December 2018 |accessdate=12 March 2019 }}</ref> and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]],<ref>{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Johnston |title=Newcastle United 0-2 Manchester United: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer wins fourth game from four |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46682775 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 January 2019 |accessdate=12 March 2019 }}</ref> scoring in both matches within two minutes of coming on. He then played the full 90 minutes of the FA Cup third round tie against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], scoring the second goal in a 2–0 win.<ref>{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Davis |title=Manchester United 2-0 Reading in FA Cup third round |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46706809 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 January 2019 |accessdate=12 March 2019 }}</ref> However, Solskjær continued to prefer to start [[Marcus Rashford]] up front and Lukaku started just five of the next nine games, playing the full 90 minutes in just two and failing to score in any of them. His goalscoring form returned for the next three games, as he scored braces against each of [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]],<ref>{{cite news |first=Shamoon |last=Hafez |title=Crystal Palace 1-3 Manchester United: Romelu Lukaku double helps visitors to victory |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47301088 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 February 2019 |accessdate=12 March 2019 }}</ref> Southampton<ref>{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Johnston |title=Manchester United 3-2 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47340490 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 March 2019 |accessdate=12 March 2019 }}</ref> and [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]. The goals against PSG were part of a 3–1 win that saw United through to the Champions League quarter-finals on the away goals rule, the first time any team had progressed after losing at home in the first leg by two goals or more.<ref>{{cite news |first=Shamoon |last=Hafez |title=Champions League: PSG 1-3 Man Utd (agg: 3-3) |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47461886 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 March 2019 |accessdate=12 March 2019 }}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Lukaku Belgium National Team vs USA 2013 (cropped).jpg|thumb|145px|left|Lukaku with [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] in May 2013]] Lukaku was a member of the [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium under-21 team]] and scored a goal on his debut against [[Slovenia national under-21 football team|Slovenia]]. On 24 February 2010, Lukaku was named for the first time in the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium senior squad]] for a [[friendly match]] against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dhnet.be/sports/diables-rouges/article/301782/romelu-lukaku-est-officiellement-diable-rouge.html#video15 |title=Romelu Lukaku est officiellement Diable Rouge |publisher=DH.be |date=24 February 2010 |accessdate=17 November 2010 |language=French}}</ref> On 17 November 2010, he scored his first two international goals in a friendly against [[Russia national football team|Russia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Russia vs Belgium Player Ratings|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/match/54146/russia-vs-belgium/report|publisher=Goal.com|date=17 November 2010}}</ref> Lukaku scored his first goal in almost two years for the national team, netting the winner in a 4–2 friendly victory over rivals the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] on 15 August 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/match/80473/belgium-vs-netherlands/report |title=Belgium 4–2 Netherlands: Mertens inspires impressive win for hosts |publisher=Goal.com |date=15 August 2012 }}</ref>
On 11 October 2013, Lukaku scored two goals as Belgium defeated Croatia 2–1 to secure a place in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] finals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2454878/Croatia-1-Belgium-2--match-report-Lukaku-double-secures-World-Cup-qualification-Red-Devils.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title=Croatia 1 Belgium 2: Lukaku double secures World Cup qualification for Red Devils |publisher=Daily Mail |date=11 October 2013 |accessdate=11 October 2013 }}</ref> In May 2014, Lukaku was named in Belgium's squad for the 2014 World Cup. On 26 May, he scored his first international hat-trick in a pre-tournament friendly against neighbouring [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27583281|title=Belgium 5–1 Luxembourg|date=26 May 2014|accessdate=27 May 2014|work=BBC}}</ref> However, as Belgium made seven [[Substitute (association football)|substitutions]] during this match instead of the permitted six, it was not recognised as an official match by [[FIFA]].<ref name="HLN040614">{{cite web|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/16076/De-Rode-Duivels/article/detail/1907260/2014/06/04/Debuut-Bossut-en-Januzaj-en-hattrick-Lukaku-zijn-ongeldig.dhtml |title=Debuut Bossut en Januzaj, én hattrick Lukaku zijn ongeldig|language=Dutch |publisher=[[Het Laatste Nieuws]] |date=4 June 2014 |accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> On 1 June, he scored first of Belgium's two goals in the 2–0 victory in a friendly match against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lukaku and Hazard score in comfortable Belgium win over Sweden|url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/world-cup-lukaku-hazard-score-comfortable-belgium-win-181057930--sow.html|publisher=Yahoo Eurosport UK|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=1 June 2014}}</ref> In Belgium's first match of the tournament, a 2–1 win against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in [[Belo Horizonte]], Lukaku started and played 58 minutes before being replaced by [[Divock Origi]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Saj|title=Belgium 2–1 Algeria|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285127|accessdate=22 June 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 June 2014}}</ref> In the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Round of 16|round of 16]], Lukaku came on as a substitute prior to [[Overtime#Association football|extra time]] and assisted [[Kevin De Bruyne]]'s opening goal three minutes later. In the 105th minute, he scored his first goal of the tournament as Belgium defeated the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27990605|title=Belgium 2–1 USA|date=1 July 2014|accessdate=2 July 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>
[[File:2017 RUS v BEL exhibition - Romelu Lukaku.jpg|thumb|145px|Lukaku playing for Belgium against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] in March 2017]] On 29 March 2016, Lukaku headed a consolation in a 2–1 loss away to [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]], assisted by his brother, [[Jordan Lukaku]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gill|first1=Kieran|title=Portugal 2–1 Belgium: Romelu Lukaku heads home cross from brother Jordan after Cristiano Ronaldo and Nani strike for hosts|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3514618/Portugal-2-1-Belgium-Romelu-Lukaku-heads-home-cross-brother-Jordan-Cristiano-Ronaldo-Nani-strike-hosts.html|accessdate=29 March 2016|work=Daily Mail|date=29 March 2016}}</ref> At [[UEFA Euro 2016]], Lukaku scored twice in Belgium's 3–0 second group stage match win on 18 June 2016 over the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Wallace |title=Belgium 3 Republic of Ireland 0: Lukaku double leaves Irish needing win against Italy to progress |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/18/belgium-3-republic-of-ireland-0-lukaku-double-leaves-irish-needi/ |website=The Daily Telegraph |date=18 June 2016 |accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref>
On 10 November 2017, Lukaku equalled the all-time Belgium goalscoring record set by [[Bernard Voorhoof]] and [[Paul van Himst]] after scoring twice against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] in a 3–3 draw.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/29908/11121930/romelu-lukaku-equals-all-time-belgium-goalscoring-record|title=Romelu Lukaku equals all-time Belgium goalscoring record|publisher=Sky Sports|date=11 November 2017|accessdate=12 November 2017}}</ref> Four days after he equalled the record, Lukaku became the Belgium’s all-time record goalscorer with 31 international goals at the age of 24 after he scored the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[Japan national football team|Japan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/11/14/manchester-united-striker-romelu-lukaku-breaks-belgium-goalscoring-record-at-the-age-of-24-7079702/|title=Manchester United striker Romelu Lukaku breaks Belgium goalscoring record at the age of 24|publisher=Metro|date=14 November 2017|accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref> Although this record was counted by the [[Royal Belgian Football Association]],<ref name="KBVBdata">{{cite web|url=http://www.belgianfootball.be/nl/alle-rode-duivels|title=Alle Rode Duivels|publisher=belgianfootball.be|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 November 2017}}</ref> FIFA only officially recognised 28 goals after a nullified international friendly match against Luxembourg on 26 May 2014 which he netted a hat trick in a 5–1 win because the former Belgium coach, [[Marc Wilmots]] made seven substitutions during the match instead of the permitted six which are not in accordance to the [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/belgium/story/3271412/fifa-doesnt-recognise-romelu-lukaku-all-time-goals-record-for-belgium|title=FIFA doesn't recognise Romelu Lukaku all-time goals record for Belgium|publisher=ESPN FC|date=15 November 2017|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/fifa-not-recognise-romelu-lukaku-11526611|title=Why FIFA does not recognise Romelu Lukaku as Belgium's all-time record goal scorer despite him netting his 31st|publisher=Mirror|date=15 November 2017|accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref>
On 6 June 2018, Lukaku officially became the Belgium's all-time leading scorer with 31 goals after scoring a goal in a 3–0 win over [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]]. He also broke a three-way tie with the previous record goalscorers, Bernard Voorhoof and Paul Van Himst.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/report?gameId=508389|title=Romelu Lukaku becomes Belgium's all-time leading scorer in win vs. Egypt|publisher=ESPN|date=6 June 2018|accessdate=8 June 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Bel-Tun (15).jpg|thumb|145px|left|Lukaku (right) playing against Tunisia in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]]]] On 18 June 2018, Lukaku scored twice in a 3–0 win over [[Panama national football team|Panama]] in their opening group game at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Belgium best debutants Panama 3-0 in Sochi |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44434275 |agency=BBC |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> In the next group game on 23 June 2018, he scored twice again in a 5–2 win over [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44439152|title=World Cup 2018: Belgium v Tunisia|date=23 June 2018|work=BBC Sport|access-date=23 June 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> In doing so, Lukaku became the first player since [[Diego Maradona]] in 1986 to score two goals or more in consecutive World Cup matches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/amp/news/lukaku-makes-world-cup-history-for-belgium/jozzix6p5v02znjc8jldvfkt|title=Red-hot Lukaku makes World Cup history for Belgium|agency=goal|access-date=23 June 2018}}</ref> He eventually ended the tournament with four goals and one assist, which earned him the Bronze Boot award, as Belgium finished the tournament in third place.<ref name="bronze boot"/>
==Style of play== Lukaku is a left-footed player,<ref>Veysey, Wayne (6 August 2011). [http://www.goal.com/en/news/755/europe/2011/08/06/2309519/meet-romelu-lukaku-the-chelsea-bound-belgian-starlet-who Belgium international shares his dreams and ambitions and reveals his intention to learn from the Ivorian at Stamford Bridge]. ''Goal''. Retrieved on 24 December 2014.</ref> who in 2014 was named by ''The Guardian'' as one of the ten most promising young players in Europe. Lukaku has also been known to use his physicality to get around defenders.<ref name="top10list" />
===Influences=== In a 2016 interview with [[ESPN]], Lukaku named [[Didier Drogba]] and [[Nicolas Anelka]] as the two strikers who made him want to play for Chelsea, but it was the mention of a third striker during the interview, his ultimate idol [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]], that he lit up with excitement, with Lukaku stating,
{{quote|"Ronaldo changed football. He was the one you would look at. You would see him doing step-overs and you were thinking: 'Who does this?' You would see defenders falling over and you were like: 'Wow.' The goals that he scored, and at crucial times. He scored goals where you were like: 'Oh man, this is not serious.'"|Lukaku speaking to ESPN on his idol, Ronaldo.<ref name="idol"/>}}
Crediting the former Brazilian striker as his major influence as a kid, Lukaku added, “He changed the dimension of a striker. He was fast, he can dribble like a winger, run like a sprinter, he was as strong as an ox.”<ref name="idol"/> His devotion to Ronaldo is such that he finds the time to search YouTube for videos of him. When mentioned that he shares certain characteristics with the Brazilian, Lukaku responded, "Be like Ronaldo? There is only one Ronaldo.”<ref name="idol">{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Rory |title=Ronaldo deserves more credit as one of the game's greatest players |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/club/brazil/205/blog/post/2840087/ronaldo-deserves-more-credit-as-one-of-the-games-best |agency=ESPN|accessdate=25 August 2018 |date=30 March 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Lukaku was born in [[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]]<ref name="ESPN">{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/player/_/id/139437/romelu-lukaku?cc=5739|title=Romelu Lukaku|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref> to [[Kongo people|Congolese]] parents.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44521723 “World Cup 2018: Romelu Lukaku says some Belgians 'want to see me fail']. BBC. Retrieved 25 September 2018</ref> His father, [[Roger Lukaku]],<ref name="TDD">{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Jeremy|title=Jose Mourinho and Real Madrid rival Chelsea for 'new Didier Drogba'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/8091041/Jose-Mourinho-and-Real-Madrid-rival-Chelsea-for-new-Didier-Drogba.html|accessdate=6 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 October 2010|location=London}}</ref> played professional football and was [[cap (sport)|capped]] at international level by [[DR Congo national football team|Zaire]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Menama Lukaku |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=93204/ |publisher=[[FIFA]] |accessdate=6 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109153304/http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player%3D93204/ |archivedate=9 November 2012 |df= }}</ref> He has a younger brother named [[Jordan Lukaku|Jordan]], who has progressed through the youth academy at Anderlecht<ref name="TDD" /> and currently plays for [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] in Italy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calcionews24.com/ss-lazio-ultime-news-e-arrivato-jordan-lukaku-ora-visite-e-firma-491724|title=Lazio, è arrivato Jordan Lukaku: ora visite e firma – Calcio News 24|first=Redazione|last=CalcioNews24|date=21 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref> His cousin [[Boli Bolingoli-Mbombo]] plays as a left-sided winger or defender for Austria's [[SK Rapid Wien|Rapid Vienna]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rapid verpflichtet Bolingoli-Mbombo von Brügge|url=https://www.skysportaustria.at/bundesliga-at/rapid-verpflichtet-bolingoli-mbombo-von-bruegge/|accessdate=31 March 2018|publisher=Sky Sports|date=22 June 2017|language=German}}</ref>
Lukaku was the subject of a television documentary series called [[:nl:De School Van Lukaku|''De School Van Lukaku'']] (Lukaku's School) shown on the Dutch-speaking Eén network. The reality show followed the teenage Lukaku and his classmates during the course of a year at the Saint-Guidon Institute, a school in [[Brussels]], where the footballer was based while with the Anderlecht youth team.<ref>[http://socqer.com/questions/819/is-it-true-that-chelsea-striker-romelu-lukaku-starred-in-a-documentary-tv-series-about-his-schooldays/#answer_922 Is it true Romelu Lukaku starred in a documentary tv series about his schooldays?] Socqer.com retrieved 7 August 2011.</ref> In 2009, the series followed the school as it made a field trip to [[London]], visiting Chelsea's Stamford Bridge ground. Lukaku said at the time, "What a stadium. If one day in my life I will cry, it will be the day I play here. I love Chelsea."<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/8687246/Chelseas-new-signing-Romelu-Lukaku-says-move-to-Stamford-Bridge-is-a-dream-come-true.html Chelsea new signing Romelu Lukaku says move to Stamford Bridge is a dream come true.] ''The Daily Telegraph'', 8 August 2011.</ref> In addition to his native French and Dutch, Lukaku can speak fluent English, Portuguese, Spanish and a Congolese Swahili dialect, and can also understand German.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/west-brom-feature-chris-lepkowski-191038|title=West Brom feature: Chris Lepkowski talks to multi-lingual Romelu Lukaku about his life and career|last=Lepkowski|first=Chris|work=Birmingham Mail|date=24 August 2012|access-date=24 August 2016}}</ref> Lukaku has stated his childhood hero and biggest idol was [[Didier Drogba]].<ref>{{cite news|title=West Brom loan star Lukaku tired of comparisons with Drogba|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2207541/Romelu-Lukaku-tired-comparisons-Didier-Drogba.html|work=Daily Mail|date=23 September 2012}}</ref>
Lukaku is a practising [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]; he made the pilgrimage to [[Lourdes]] in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |first=May |last=Bulman |title=Romelu Lukaku: British tabloids wrongly claim black Christian footballer is 'devout Muslim' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/romelu-lukaku-british-tabloids-christian-black-devout-muslim-manchester-united-daily-mail-sun-a7862506.html |work=The Independent Online |publisher=Independent Digital News & Media |date=27 July 2017 |accessdate=31 July 2017 }}</ref> He does not drink alcohol.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/oct/18/miqdaad-versi-very-polite-fight-against-british-media-islamophobia</ref>
===Media and endorsements=== Lukaku was the first Premier League player to join Jay-Z's management agency [[Roc Nation Sports]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rocnation.com/romelu-lukaku/|title=ROMELU LUKAKU|website=roc nation|date=1 March 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref> In 2018, Lukaku signed a record sponsorship deal with German sportswear company [[Puma SE|Puma]], the company’s largest endorsement deal ever.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United's Romelu Lukaku signs record Puma sponsorship deal |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/manchester-united/story/3526838/manchester-uniteds-romelu-lukaku-signs-record-puma-sponsorship-deal |agency=ESPN |date=19 June 2018}}</ref>
