'''Christopher Lloyd Smalling''' (born 22 November 1989) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre back]] for {{English football updater|ManchesU}} club [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and the [[England national football team|England national team]].
During his youth, Smalling played for the [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] academy before joining non-League club [[Maidstone United F.C.|Maidstone United]]. After establishing himself in the Maidstone United first team, he signed for [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in May 2008. However, shortly after joining Middlesbrough, Smalling had his contract with the club cancelled after raising concerns over homesickness. Soon after, in June 2008, he signed for Premier League club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. He made his professional debut with them in May 2009 and helped them reach the [[2010 UEFA Europa League Final]] the following season.
In January 2010, Smalling signed a pre-contract agreement with Manchester United and joined them officially in July 2010. He made his competitive debut in the [[2010 FA Community Shield]] victory over [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], which earned him his first career medal. Since his debut, he has gone on to make more than 200 appearances for the club, winning two Premier League titles, an [[FA Cup]], a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]], a [[UEFA Europa League]] and a further two [[FA Community Shield|Community Shields]].
Smalling represented the [[English Schools Football Association|England Schools under-18 team]] in early 2008, before making his debut for the national [[England national under-20 football team|under-20]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] teams in 2009. He made his senior international debut in September 2011 and has appeared at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] and [[UEFA Euro 2016]].
==Club career== ===Maidstone United=== Smalling was born in [[Greenwich]], London.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chris Smalling |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/chris-smalling-229771/ |work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref> He is of Jamaican descent.<ref>{{cite news |first=Alistair |last=Tweedale |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/09/euro-2016-one-in-three-players-could-play-for-another-country/ |title=One in three players at Euro 2016 could play for another country |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=9 June 2016 |accessdate=8 July 2017}}</ref> As a youngster he played for Walderslade Boys and Lordswood.<ref>{{cite news|first=Laura |last=Williamson |title=Chris Smalling's giant leap: A call from Sir Alex Ferguson and the journey from Maidstone United to Manchester United – via Fulham – is complete |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1246885/Chris-Smallings-giant-leap-A-Sir-Alex-Ferguson-journey-Maidstone-United-Manchester-United--Fulham--complete.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=29 January 2010 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> After a short spell at [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]'s [[Football academy|academy]], a 16-year-old Smalling joined [[Maidstone United F.C.|Maidstone United]]'s youth set-up and continued his education at [[Chatham Grammar School for Boys]].<ref name="express.co.uk">{{cite news|first=Richard |last=Jolly |title=Chris Smalling steps up to prove his class |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/276373/Chris-Smalling-steps-up-to-prove-his-class |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=9 October 2011 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref>
After rising through Maidstone United's youth and reserve team set-up under the tutelage of coaches Peter Nott and Tony Cornwell,<ref name="express.co.uk"/> Smalling made his first-team debut for 'The Stones' on 11 April 2007, in a 4–1 loss against [[Tonbridge Angels F.C.|Tonbridge Angels]] in the [[Kent Senior Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Ruth |last=Tunnell |title=Maidstone United 1–4 Tonbridge Angels |url=http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/matchday/0607season/kentseniorcup/tonbridge_home.htm |publisher=Maidstone United F.C. |date=11 April 2007 |accessdate=13 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605114833/http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/matchday/0607season/kentseniorcup/tonbridge_home.htm |archive-date=5 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After making further appearances in the [[FA Trophy]] and [[Alan Turvey Trophy|Isthmian League Cup]], Smalling made his league debut for the club in December 2007, playing the full 90 minutes in a 1–1 draw against [[Harlow Town F.C.|Harlow Town]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Ruth |last=Tunnell |title=Maidstone United 1–1 Harlow Town |url=http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/matchday/0708season/harlowtown/home.htm |publisher=Maidstone United F.C. |date=11 December 2007 |accessdate=11 December 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221025901/http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/matchday/0708season/harlowtown/home.htm |archive-date=21 December 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Smalling impressed and quickly established himself as a vital part of Maidstone United's back line; however, injury and international duty restricted him to making only 11 league appearances for the Kent club.<ref>{{cite web |title=The rise and rise of Chris Smalling |url=http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/news/2009/smalling.htm |publisher=Maidstone United F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605121636/http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/news/2009/smalling.htm |archivedate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Smalling scored one goal for Maidstone United, in a 4–2 win at [[East Thurrock United F.C.|East Thurrock United]] on 24 March 2008, a match which was also his last appearance for the club.<ref>{{cite web |first=Ruth |last=Tunnell |title=East Thurrock United 2–4 Maidstone United |url=http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/matchday/0708season/eastthurrockunited/away.htm |publisher=Maidstone United F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728091044/http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/matchday/0708season/eastthurrockunited/away.htm |archivedate=28 July 2013 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
===Fulham=== [[File:Smalling.JPG|thumb|upright|Smalling warming up for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in 2009]]
After attracting strong interest from [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]], [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] and [[Reading F.C.|Reading]],<ref name=msu08>{{cite web |title=News – February 2008 |url=http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/news/2008/0802.htm |publisher=Maidstone United F.C. |date=18 February 2008 |accessdate=30 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605112614/http://www.maidstoneunited.co.uk/news/2008/0802.htm |archive-date=5 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Smalling signed for [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on a two-year contract on 30 April 2008.<ref name=msu08/><ref>{{cite news |first=Colin |last=Young |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-564389/Boro-boost-ranks-young-England-defender-Smalling-signs-The-Riverside.html |title=Boro boost their ranks as young England defender Smalling signs on at The Riverside |accessdate=6 May 2008 |date=6 May 2008 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> However, within a month of signing, his contract with Middlesbrough was cancelled, with Smalling concerned about homesickness,<ref>{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Howard |title=Craven Cottage switch for Boro signing Smalling |url=http://www.kentnews.co.uk/sport/craven_cottage_switch_for_boro_signing_smalling_1_1040805 |publisher=Kent News |date=30 May 2008 |accessdate=10 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205095122/http://www.kentnews.co.uk/sport/craven_cottage_switch_for_boro_signing_smalling_1_1040805 |archive-date=5 December 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and in June 2008, he signed for [[Premier League]] club Fulham.<ref>{{cite web|last=Beattie |first=Chris |url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/chris-smalling-fulham-move-proof-theres-talent-outside-football-league-220069 |title=Chris Smalling: Fulham move proof there's talent outside Football League |accessdate=10 December 2013|date=4 January 2009 |publisher=Tribal Football}}</ref> Smalling was not on a contract at Maidstone United, for it would have prohibited him from playing for England Schoolboys, and as such the [[Isthmian League]] club were not entitled to a fee for the player; however, Fulham struck a deal which saw Maidstone United given £10,000 upon the transfer and £10,000 for every 10 league matches he played.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chris Smalling: Sam Wallace: It's sad that Maidstone miss out on share of £10m Smalling windfall |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/sam-wallace-its-sad-that-maidstone-miss-out-on-share-of-16310m-smalling-windfall-1892299.html |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=8 February 2010 |accessdate=8 February 2010}}</ref> He was made captain of the club's Development Squad by manager [[Billy McKinlay]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Pathway to Success |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2009/june/04/pathway-to-success |publisher=Fulham F.C. |date=4 June 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
On 24 May 2009, Smalling made his Premier League debut for Fulham, replacing [[Aaron Hughes]] in the 77th minute in the final match of the [[2008–09 Premier League|2008–09 season]], a 2–0 home loss to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/match-centre/2008_2009/league/home/everton |title=Fulham v Everton |date=24 May 2009 |publisher=Fulham F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212160341/http://www.fulhamfc.com/match-centre/2008_2009/league/home/everton |archivedate=12 December 2013 |df=dmy}}</ref> Smalling made his first start for Fulham on 17 September 2009, in an away tie with [[CSKA Sofia]] in the [[UEFA Europa League]], with the match ending 1–1.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Lyon |title=CSKA Sofia 1–1 Fulham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8254990.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 September 2009 |accessdate=17 September 2009}}</ref> On 28 December 2009, Smalling made his first league start for Fulham, in a 2–1 loss against Chelsea at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in Fulham's final match of 2009 and scored a decisive [[own goal]] in the 75th minute of the match.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Hughes |title=Chelsea 2–1 Fulham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8428887.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2009 |accessdate=28 December 2009}}</ref> He was not included in the matchday squad for the [[2010 UEFA Europa League Final]], in which Fulham were beaten 2–1 after [[extra time]] by [[Atlético Madrid]] at the [[Volksparkstadion]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Atletico Madrid 2–1 Fulham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8675486.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 May 2010 |accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
===Manchester United=== On 27 January 2010, [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] announced that they had signed Smalling, for an undisclosed fee, with the player staying at Fulham for the remainder of the [[2009–10 Fulham F.C. season|2009–10 season]] before joining United for the beginning 2010–11 campaign.<ref>{{cite web|first=Ben |last=Hibbs |title=Reds swoop for Smalling |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2010/Jan/Reds-swoop-for-Smalling.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=26 January 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> The transfer officially went through on 1 July 2010.<ref>{{cite web|first=James |last=Tuck |title=Pair become United players |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2010/Jul/Pair-become-United-players.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=17 July 2010}}</ref>
====2010–2014==== Smalling made his debut for United on 8 August 2010 in the [[2010 FA Community Shield]], appearing as a second-half [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 3–1 win over Chelsea.<ref name=2010FACS>{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Fletcher |title=Chelsea 1–3 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8893192.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> His Premier League debut for United came in their 3–0 home win over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 28 August 2010, coming on as a 74th-minute substitute for [[Jonny Evans]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Nabil |last=Hassan |title=Manchester United 3–0 West Ham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8946431.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 August 2010 |accessdate=28 August 2010}}</ref> On 15 September 2010, he made his [[UEFA Champions League]] debut, playing the full 90 minutes in a 0–0 draw at home against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Man Utd 0–0 Rangers |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8994314.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> Eight days later, Smalling scored his first goal for Manchester United, also his first senior career goal, in a 5–2 away win over [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] in the [[2010–11 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Ashenden |title=Scunthorpe 2–5 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/9010117.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> Smalling then made his full Premier League debut for United on 4 January 2011, partnering [[Nemanja Vidić]] for the full 90 minutes in a 2–1 home win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Stevenson |title=Man Utd 3–1 Stoke |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9334445.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Chris Smalling and Wes Brown cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Smalling playing for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in 2011]]
On 8 July 2011, Smalling signed a new five-year contract with United.<ref>{{cite web |first=Adam |last=Marshall |title=New deal for Smalling |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2011/Jul/smalling-signs-new-contract.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}}</ref> Smalling scored his first goal of the [[2011–12 Manchester United F.C. season|2011–12 season]] in the [[2011 FA Community Shield]] against United's local rivals [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], volleying in an [[Ashley Young]] free kick from close range to reduce the deficit to 2–1.<ref name=2011FACS>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Manchester City 2–3 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14420151 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> Manchester United went on to win the match 3–2 and take the Shield.<ref name=2011FACS/> The new season also saw Smalling adapt to a new role, as early injuries to Nemanja Vidić and [[Rio Ferdinand]] allowed Smalling, Jonny Evans and new signing [[Phil Jones (footballer, born 1992)|Phil Jones]] to replace them.<ref name=august2011guardian>{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |title=Sir Alex Ferguson puts faith in his young Manchester United defenders|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/19/alex-ferguson-faith-young-defence |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> Evans and Jones played as central defenders, whereas Smalling was deployed as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]].<ref name=august2011guardian/> Smalling scored his first ever Premier League goal, against Chelsea at [[Old Trafford]], on 18 September 2011, rising unmarked to place a [[Header (association football)|header]] into the far corner to open the scoring in a match United went on to win 3–1.<ref>{{cite web |first=Adam |last=Marshall |title=United 3 Chelsea 1|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2011/Sep/manchester-united-vs-chelsea-match-report.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=18 September 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> Smalling was ruled out of the last Premier League fixture of the season and also for England's [[UEFA Euro 2012]] campaign due to a groin injury he sustained during Manchester United's 2–0 win over [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in the penultimate week of the league season.<ref>{{cite web |first=James |last=Tuck |title=Smalling out of Euro 2012 |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2012/May/manchester-united-team-news-v-sunderland.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=11 May 2012 |accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref>
On 21 July 2012, it was announced that Smalling would miss the start of the season after being ruled out for 10 weeks after undergoing surgery on a broken metatarsal.<ref>{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |title=Manchester United's Chris Smalling out for up to 10 weeks|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jul/21/manchester-united-chris-smalling-injury |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=21 July 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> The injury had ruled him out of the entire pre-season tour.<ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=McDonnell |title=Teenage kicks: Rio's the only experienced centre-back on United pre-season tour|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/manchester-uniteds-rio-ferdinand-is-the-only-1145170 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=16 July 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> He made his return on 7 November 2012, playing the full 90 minutes in a 3–1 win away to Portuguese team [[S.C. Braga|Braga]] in the Champions League.<ref>{{cite news |first=Gary |last=Rose |title=Braga 1–3 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20150369 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 November 2012 |accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> He made his Premier League return three days later, helping his team to a 3–2 win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Smith |title=Aston Villa 2–3 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20190153 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 November 2012 |accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref>
On 27 November 2013, Smalling scored his first Champions League goal in a 5–0 win away to [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |title=Bayer Leverkusen 0–5 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25108342 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2013 |accessdate=27 November 2013}}</ref> On 26 December 2013, he scored in a 3–2 win against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Graham |last=Chase |title=Hull City 2–3 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25442218 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref>
Smalling was [[Red card (association football)|sent off]] in the first half of United's 1–0 defeat in the [[Manchester derby]] on 2 November 2014.<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Manchester City 1–0 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29775977 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 November 2014 |accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> Manager [[Louis van Gaal]] deemed Smalling "stupid" for his second yellow card in the match, awarded for a foul on [[James Milner]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd: Louis Van Gaal angry at 'stupid' Chris Smalling |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29872266 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 November 2014 |accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> On 29 November 2014, he scored his first Premier League goal of the season in a 3–0 victory over Hull City at Old Trafford, it was also his first Old Trafford goal in three years.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Manchester United 3–0 Hull City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30156606 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 November 2014 |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
====2015–present==== [[File:Chris Smalling vs Rostov 9 March 2017 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Smalling lining up for Manchester United in 2017]]
On 11 February 2015, Smalling became the first player in the history of the Premier League to score two first-half goals as a substitute, after appearing as a 5th-minute substitute in a 3–1 victory against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Ogden |title=Manchester United 3 Burnley 1: Two goals from Chris Smalling bright spots in abject performance |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/11406409/Manchester-United-3-Burnley-1-Two-goals-from-Chris-Smalling-bright-spots-in-abject-performance.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Chris Smalling joins Frank Lampard and Cristiano Ronaldo in setting world record |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/11843144/Chris-Smalling-joins-Frank-Lampard-and-Cristiano-Ronaldo-in-setting-world-record.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=4 September 2015 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> On 12 April 2015, he scored his fourth league goal of the season in a 4–2 win over Manchester City.<ref>{{cite web |title=Smalling helps United snatch bragging rights away from City |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2015/Apr/12/sunday-premier-league-england-roundup-120415 |publisher=The Football Association |date=12 April 2015 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> Nine days later, Smalling signed a new contract with Manchester United, keeping him at the club until June 2019.<ref>{{cite web |title=Smalling signs new contract |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2015/Apr/chris-smalling-signs-new-manchester-united-contract.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=21 April 2015 |accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref> Having been praised by manager Louis van Gaal for his command of the defensive unit, Smalling captained United for the first time on 17 May 2015 during a 1–1 draw against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/chris-smalling-named-manchester-united-5712485 |title=Chris Smalling named Manchester United captain for clash with Arsenal at Old Trafford |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=17 May 2015 |accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/577882/Louis-van-Gaal-Chris-Smalling-Arsenal-Man-Utd |title=Louis van Gaal: Why I named Chris Smalling captain for Arsenal clash |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |first=David |last=Wright |date=17 May 2015 |accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref>
On 2 May 2016, Smalling won the Manchester United Players' Player of the Year award.<ref name=playerofyear>{{cite web|title=Smalling voted Players' Player of the Year |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2016/May/POTY-Chris-Smalling-voted-Manchester-United-Players-Player-of-the-Year-2016.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=2 May 2016 |accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> Later that month, on 21 May, he was sent off against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the [[2016 FA Cup Final]], which Manchester United won 2–1 after extra time.<ref name=2016FAC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36292265 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2016 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref>
He scored his first goal of the [[2016–17 Manchester United F.C. season|2016–17 season]] on 24 September with a 22nd-minute header which opened the scoring in a 4–1 victory over reigning Premier League champions, [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37393483|title=Manchester United 4–1 Leicester City|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Tom|last=Rostance|date=24 September 2016|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== [[File:Chris Smalling.JPG|thumb|upright|Smalling playing for the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] in 2009]]
At the age of 17 and studying for his [[GCE Advanced Level|A Levels]], Smalling was selected to represent his county ([[Kent]]), and the Kent Schools' Football Association then nominated him for trials for the [[English Schools' Football Association|England Schoolboy international squad]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Under 18 England Schools International Trials |url=http://www.esfa.co.uk/news/?2007/11/13/153535/U18_England_Schoolboys_International_Trials |publisher=England Schools Football Association |date=13 November 2007 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref> His trial was successful, and Smalling was selected to represent England Schools against Australia in January 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=England Schoolboys Under 18 International Squad |url=http://www.esfa.co.uk/news/?2008/01/16/164914 |publisher=England Schools Football Association |date=29 January 2008 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref> England won 2–0,<ref>{{cite web |title=England 2–0 Australia |url=http://www.esfa.co.uk/news/?2008/01/29/132324/ |publisher=England Schools Football Association |date=29 January 2008 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref> and Smalling went on to play for England in the Centenary Shield, playing all four matches which including 1–0 victory against Wales Schools in which he scored the only goal.<ref>{{cite web |title=ESFA International Fixtures 2007–2008 |url=http://www.esfa.co.uk/international/?view=2007 |publisher=England Schools Football Association |date=13 November 2010 |accessdate=13 November 2010}}</ref>
Smalling made his debut for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] 31 March 2009, playing 45 minutes in a 2–0 win against [[Italy national under-20 football team|Italy]] at [[Loftus Road]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Lions' Loftus roar |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u20s/News/2009/italy_310309_report |publisher=The Football Association |date=31 March 2009 |accessdate=31 March 2009}}</ref> On 11 August, four months after his under-20 debut, he made his debut for the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 squad]] in a friendly fixture against the [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands]], coming on as a substitute in the 58th minute of a 0–0 away draw.<ref>{{cite web |title=New-look Under-21s draw comfort in Holland |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2009/England%20v%20Holland/HollandvEngland_report |publisher=The Football Association |date=11 August 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref> On 14 November, Smalling made first start for the under-21s in a [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualifier]] against [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] in a 1–0 win.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rose blooms as England beat Portugal |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2009/EnglandvPortugal/Report |publisher=The Football Association |date=14 November 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the under-21s on 8 October 2010, against Romania, in England's [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification play-offs|2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification play-off]] first leg, converting from inside the area after an assist from [[Daniel Sturridge]]. The goal, scored in the 83rd minute, proved to be the winner as England won 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Williams |title=Chris Smalling gives England slender advantage over Romania Under-21s |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/oct/08/england-romania-under-21-euro-2011-qualifier |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=8 October 2010 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
===Senior=== On 13 November 2010, Smalling was called up to the [[England national football team|England senior squad]] for the first time for their [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] against [[France national football team|France]] on 17 November;<ref>{{cite web|title=Capello names squad |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/News/match-centre/2010/EnglandvFrance/Previews/Squad-named |publisher=The Football Association|date=13 November 2010 |accessdate=14 November 2010}}</ref> however, he was an unused substitute in the 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 1–2 France |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/9194622.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 November 2010 |accessdate=24 November 2010}}</ref> He made his senior debut in the [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying|UEFA Euro 2012 qualifier]] against [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] on 2 September 2011, which England won 3–0, in which he played at right back.<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Bulgaria 0–3 England |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14770875.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 September 2011 |accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref>
On 12 May 2014, Smalling was named in England's 23-man squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2014: England name Ross Barkley in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27362447 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 May 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> With England's elimination from the [[2014 FIFA World Cup Group D|group stages]] already confirmed, Smalling was given a tournament debut as a starter in the final group match, helping the team to a clean sheet in a 0–0 draw with [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] in [[Belo Horizonte]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |title=England end disappointing World Cup with barren draw against Costa Rica |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/24/costa-rica-england-world-cup-group-d-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=24 June 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>
On 31 May 2016, Smalling was named in England's 23-man squad for [[UEFA Euro 2016]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Euro 2016: Marcus Rashford in England squad – Townsend and Drinkwater miss out |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36413882 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 May 2016 |accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> On 2 June 2016, in England's final warm-up match for Euro 2016, he scored his first goal for England in a 1–0 victory over [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Chris Smalling swoops to give limp England victory over 10-man Portugal |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/02/england-portugal-international-friendly-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=2 June 2016 |accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref>
Smalling was dropped by England manager [[Gareth Southgate]] in November 2017, as Southgate felt players such as [[John Stones]], [[Harry Maguire]] and [[Eric Dier]] were better at initiating the play. Smalling registered his surprise and responded, "I'm as good a defender as anyone."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/nov/21/chris-smalling-gareth-southgate-england-defender|title='I’m as good a defender as anyone,' Chris Smalling tells England manager|date=21 November 2017|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> He was not included in the squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}}

{{Marriage|Joseph Feury|1962}} | children = [[Dinah Manoff]] }} '''Lee Grant''' (born '''Lyova Haskell Rosenthal'''; October 31, during the mid-1920s){{efn|name="birth year note"}} is an American actress and film director. In her 1951 film debut, she played the role of a young shoplifter in [[William Wyler]]'s ''[[Detective Story (1951 film)|Detective Story]]'', co-starring [[Kirk Douglas]] and [[Eleanor Parker]]. It earned her an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]], along with the Best Actress Award at the [[1952 Cannes Film Festival]]. In 1952, as she had refused to testify against her husband at the [[HUAC]] hearings, she was [[Hollywood ten|blacklisted]] from most acting jobs for the next ten years. She was then only able to find occasional work on the stage or as a teacher during that period. It also contributed to her divorce. After she was removed from the blacklist in 1962, she rebuilt her acting career in films, after which she starred in 71 TV episodes of ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)|Peyton Place]]'' (1965–1966), followed by lead roles in films such as ''[[Valley of the Dolls (film)|Valley of the Dolls]]'' (1967), ''[[In the Heat of the Night (film)|In the Heat of the Night]]'' (1967), and ''[[Shampoo (film)|Shampoo]]'' (1975), for which she won her first Oscar. In 1964, she won the [[Obie Award for Distinguished Performance by an Actress]] for her performance in ''[[The Maids]]''. During her career, she was nominated for the [[Emmy Award]] seven times between 1966 and 1993, winning twice. ==Early life== Lee Grant was born Lyova Haskell RosenthalRoberts, Jerry. ''Encyclopedia of Television Film Directors'', Scarecrow Press, 1st edition (June 5, 2009), Amazon Digital Services, Inc; ASIN: B009W3C7E8Katz, Ephraim. ''The Film Encyclopedia'', Harper Perennial (1998) p. 552; {{ISBN|0-06-273492-X}} in [[Manhattan]], the only child of Witia ([[married and maiden names|née]] Haskell), an actress and teacher, and Abraham W. Rosenthal, a realtor and educator. Her father was born in New York City, to [[Polish-Jewish]] immigrants, and her mother was a [[Russian-Jewish]] immigrant.[http://forward.com/articles/202192/lee-grant-said-yes-to-everything-except-mccarth Profile], forward.com; accessed September 9, 2014. The family resided at 706 [[Riverside Drive (Manhattan)|Riverside Drive]], in the [[Hamilton Heights]] neighborhood of Manhattan.[http://www.filmreference.com/film/38/Lee-Grant.html Lee Grant profile], FilmReference.com; accessed September 9, 2014. Her date of birth is October 31, but the year is disputed, with all years ranging from 1925 to 1931 having been given as her year of birth at some point; however, census data, travel manifests, and testimony suggest that she was born in 1925 or 1926, while Grant's stated ages at the time of her professional debut and Oscar nomination indicate she was born in 1927.{{efn|name="birth year note"}} She debuted in ''[[Franco Leoni|L'Oracolo]]'' at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in 1931Olin Downes. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A05E0D71738E133A25757C2A9679D946094D6CF&legacy=true The Opera: Scotti Cheered as Chim-Fen in "L'Oracolo"-Tribute to Mme. Jeritza in "Cavalleria."] November 24, 1931. The New York Times. "Hoo-Chee...Lyova Rosenthal"{{cite news |title=Movie Memory Lee Grant 1976 |date=December 1, 2002 |work=[[New York Daily News]] |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/movie-memory-lee-grant-1976-article-1.495393 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}} and later joined the [[American Ballet]] as an adolescent.Gray, Spalding. ''Life Interrupted: The Unfinished Monologue'', Random House (2005) p. 154 She attended [[Art Students League of New York]], [[Juilliard School of Music]], [[The High School of Music & Art]], and [[George Washington High School (New York City)|George Washington High School]], all in New York City. Grant graduated from high school, and won a scholarship to the [[Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre]], and studied under [[Sanford Meisner]]. Studied at [[HB Studio]][https://hbstudio.org/about-hb-studio/alumni/ HB Studio Alumni] under [[Uta Hagen]]. She subsequently enrolled in [[Actors Studio]] in New York. ==Career== ===1940s{{ndash}}1950s=== Grant had her first stage ballet performance in 1933 at the [[Metropolitan Opera House (39th Street)|Metropolitan Opera House]].[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/person/75242%7C96586/Lee-Grant/milestones.html Turner Classic Movies] In 1938, in her early teens, she was made a member of the [[American Ballet]], under [[George Balanchine]]. As an actress, Grant had her professional stage debut as understudy in ''Oklahoma'' in 1944. In 1948, she had her Broadway acting debut in ''Joy to the World''. Grant established herself as a dramatic [[method acting|method]] actress on and off [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], earning praise for her role as a shoplifter in ''[[Detective Story (play)|Detective Story]]'' in 1949.{{IBDB name|42830}} She made her film debut two years later in the film version (''[[Detective Story (1951 film)|Detective Story]]''), starring [[Kirk Douglas]], receiving her first [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] nomination, and winning the [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actress]] Award at the [[Cannes Film Festival]].[[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)]] She said she enjoyed working under director [[William Wyler]], who helped guide her.Interview: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AL3iv9gUAPA;t=1m43s Lee Grant, "Inside the Actors Studio" 1998] {{quote box||align=right|width=25em|bgcolor = MistyRose|quote=But as quickly as that dream unfolded, her life soon turned into a nightmare... So right when her career should have been blooming, she was banned from working in Hollywood. And that ban lasted for twelve years, a lifetime for an actor.|source=[[Robert Osborne]], ''Turner Classic Movies'' interview[http://www.tcm.com/mediaroom/video/1033419/Conversation-With-Lee-Grant-A-TCM-Original-2014.html "Conversation With Lee Grant", 2014], tcm.com; accessed May 5, 2017.}} In 1951, she gave an impassioned eulogy at the memorial service for actor [[J. Edward Bromberg]], whose early death, she implied, was caused by the stress of being called before [[House Un-American Activities Committee]] (HUAC). After her eulogy was published, she was summoned by the same committee to testify against her husband, playwright [[Arnold Manoff]], but refused. As a result, for the next ten years, her "prime years", as she put it,[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/lee-grant-on-life-beyond-the-hollywood-blacklist "Lee Grant on life beyond the Hollywood blacklist"], CBSnews.com, August 3, 2014. she was [[Hollywood ten|blacklisted]] and her work in television and movies was limited.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7YLf3Ga4ZBM Turner Classic Movies "Evening With Lee Grant" (1of4), ''Detective Story''], interview with [[Robert Osborne]], 2014 [[Kirk Douglas]], who acted with her in ''Detective Story'', recalled that director [[Edward Dmytryk]], a blacklistee, had first named her husband at the HUAC:{{quote|Lee was only a kid, a beautiful young girl with extraordinary talent and a big future. You could see it. She was so good that she earned a Best Supporting Actress nomination for her very first film role. But because Eddie Dmytryk named her husband, Lee Grant was blacklisted before her film career even had a chance to begin. Of course, she refused to testify about the man to whom she was married, and it took years before anyone would hire her for another picture.Douglas, Kirk. ''I Am Spartacus: Making a Film, Breaking the Blacklist'', Open Road Media (2012) p. 26; {{ISBN|978-1453254806}}}} Grant appeared in a limited number of stage and television shows during these years. In 1953, she played Rose Peabody on the [[Columbia Broadcasting Company|CBS]] [[soap opera]], ''[[Search for Tomorrow]]''. In the Broadway production of ''[[Two for the Seesaw]]'' in 1959, she succeeded [[Anne Bancroft]] in the lead female role.[http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/lee-grant/11/ "Two for the Seesaw"], CBS News, 2017 ===1960s=== [[File:Lee Grant - 1961.jpg|thumb|upright=.80|Grant in 1961]] By the time her name was finally removed from the blacklist in the early 1960s, she had since been divorced, remarried, and had a young daughter, [[Dinah Manoff|Dinah]]. She began re-establishing her television and movie career. In her autobiography, she writes:{{quote|Dinah was my grail, my constant; nothing and no one could get between us. Dinah and my need to support her financially, morally, viscerally, and my rage at those who had taken twelve working, acting years from my life, were what motivated me.Grant, Lee. ''I Said Yes to Everything: A Memoir'', Penguin (2014) {{ISBN|978-0-399-16930-4}}{{rp|250}}}} Her experience with the blacklist scarred her to such an extent that as late as 2002, she would freeze and go into a "near trance" when anyone asked her about her experiences during the McCarthy period.Ross, Steven J. ''Hollywood Left and Right'', Oxford Univ. Press (2011) p. 128; {{ISBN|978-0195181722}} Grant's first major achievement, after HUAC officially cleared her, was in the 1960s television series ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)|Peyton Place]]'', as [[Stella Chernak]], for which she won an [[Primetime Emmy Award|Emmy]] in 1966. In 1967, Grant appeared in an episode of ''[[Mission Impossible]]'', portraying the wife of a U.S. diplomat who goes undercover to discredit a rogue diplomat. That same year, she played the distraught widow of a murder victim in the Oscar-winning ''[[In the Heat of the Night (film)|In the Heat of the Night]]''. In 1963, she won acclaim for her stage performance in the off-Broadway production of [[Jean Genet]]'s ''[[The Maids]]''.{{iobdb name|15613}} ===1970s=== She received subsequent Academy Award nominations for the dramas ''[[The Landlord]]'' (1970) and ''[[Voyage of the Damned]]'' (1976). Her acting range extended into comedy equally well, notably in several roles as an overbearing mother. In ''[[Plaza Suite (film)|Plaza Suite]]'' (1971), a comedy directed by [[Arthur Hiller]] and written by [[Neil Simon]], she played the harassed mother of a bride, with [[Walter Matthau]] as the father. The film was followed by another comedy role as the mother in ''[[Portnoy's Complaint (film)|Portnoy's Complaint]]'' (1972). Also in 1971, she played cold-blooded killer Leslie Williams in the second episode ("Ransom for a Dead Man") of the [[Peter Falk]] series ''[[List of Columbo episodes|Columbo]]''. She would appear with Falk again on Broadway ''[[Prisoner of Second Avenue]]'', whose playwright Neil Simon said that his "first and only choice" for the part was Grant, who he said was equally at home with dramatists such as [[Chekhov]] or [[Sidney Kingsley]], yet could also be "hilariously funny" when the script called for it, as she was able to portray essential honesty in her acting.Simon, Neil. ''Rewrites'', Simon & Schuster (1996) p. 336) Among her most notable roles was as [[Warren Beatty]]'s older lover in ''[[Shampoo (film)|Shampoo]]'' (1975), for which she won an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] for Best Supporting Actress. The film received mixed reviews, but was Columbia's biggest hit in the studio's 50-year history.Ford, Elizabeth. ''The Makeover in Movies: Before and After in Hollywood Films, 1941-2002'', McFarland (2004) p. 198 ''[[Shampoo (film)|Shampoo]]'' was the second film in which Grant acted under director [[Hal Ashby]]. Critic [[Pauline Kael]], comparing her in both films, noted Grant "is such a cool-style comedienne that she's in danger of having people say that she's good, as usual."[[Pauline Kael|Kael, Pauline]]. ''The Age of Movies: Selected Writings of Pauline Kael'', Penguin e-books (2011) During the filming, however, she did have some serious disagreements with Beatty, who was also the producer, and nearly quit. During one scene, she wanted to play it in a way she felt was more realistic from a woman's perspective, but Beatty disagreed. After thinking about the scene for a few days, she told director Ashby that she could not do it Beatty's way and was quitting. As she was walking out, Beatty stopped her, and asked what was wrong. "I sat down and told him", she said. "He threw up his hands and said, 'Play it your way. What do I know? I'm a man.'"Biskind, Peter. ''Star: The Life and Wild Times of Warren Beatty'', Simon & Schuster (2010) e-book [[file:Lee Grant 1975-1.jpg|thumb|upright=.80|Grant in 1975]] Despite the success of the film, Grant was feeling less secure in Hollywood, as she was then around fifty years old. She writes: {{quote|I was becoming my own worst enemy as an actor, traumatized onstage and fixated on staying young so I could keep working in film. A woman of a certain age does not play in movies or TV; we're kicked to the side or out. And I was a woman of a certain age, terrified I'd be found out and unemployed again.{{rp|213}}}} In March 1971, Grant appeared in the ''[[Columbo (TV series)|Columbo]]'' episode "Ransom for a Dead Man"', and was nominated for an Emmy as Outstanding Lead Actress – Miniseries or a Movie. Having been nominated for two performances in the same acting category, she received the award for her other Emmy-nominated performance in the television film, ''The Neon Ceiling''. The only other nominee was [[Colleen Dewhurst]]; in Grant's acceptance speech, she wryly noted, "I must thank Colleen Dewhurst since it takes two of me to equal one of her." {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} During the 1975-76 television season, she starred in the [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Fay (TV series)|Fay]]'', which, to her chagrin, was canceled after eight episodes. She made a guest appearance on ''[[Empty Nest (TV series)|Empty Nest]]'', in which her daughter [[Dinah Manoff]] co-starred. In 1978 she was the lead actress in the sequel, ''[[Damien: Omen II]]''. Grant successfully moved into directing when she directed the stage play, ''[[The Stronger]]'', in 1976, written by [[August Strindberg]]. ===1980s{{ndash}}1990s=== In 1980, Grant directed her first film, ''[[Tell Me a Riddle (film)|Tell Me a Riddle]]'', a story about an aging Jewish couple. That debut narrative film was followed by a widely distributed documentary film, "The Willmar 8", which profiled 8 female employees of a bank in Willmar, Minnesota who went on strike to protest pay inequities between male and female bank tellers. She starred a [[HBO]] remake of ''[[Plaza Suite]]'' in 1982, costarring [[Jerry Orbach]], both playing three different characters in three acts. It was filmed before a live audience.Shelley, Peter. ''Neil Simon on Screen: Adaptations and Original Scripts for Film and Television'', McFarland (2015) p. 55[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWjMuf5IUeM Scene from ''Plaza Suite'' (1982), Act II, Lee Grant & Jerry Orbach] [[File:Lee Grant at F.I.S.T premier 1978.jpg|thumb|upright=.76|left|Grant at the premiere of ''F.I.S.T.'' (April 1978)]] Actor [[Bruce Dern]], who played alongside her in [[The Big Town (1987 film)|''The Big Town'']] (1987), recalls working with her: "Lee Grant is a fabulous actress. Anytime she works it's a blessing you have her in your movie."[[Bruce Dern|Dern, Bruce]]. ''Things I've Said, But Probably Shouldn't Have: An Unrepentant Memoir'', Wiley (2007) p. 231 She directed several documentary films, including ''[[Down and Out in America]]'' (1986) which won the [[Academy Award for Documentary Feature]]. That same year, she directed ''Nobody's Child'', a television movie starring [[Marlo Thomas]] about a woman confined to a mental institution for twenty years.{{IMDb name|0335519}} For her direction, Grant became the first female director to win the [[Directors Guild of America Award]]. In 1988, she was awarded the [[Women in Film Crystal + Lucy Awards#THE CRYSTAL AWARD|Women in Film Crystal Award]] for outstanding women who through their endurance and the excellence of their work have helped to expand the role of women within the entertainment industry.[http://wif.org/past-recipients Profile] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724120329/http://www.wif.org/past-recipients |date=2011-07-24 }} Women in Film website; accessed September 9, 2014. Admiring her directing and acting skill, actress [[Sissy Spacek]] agreed to act in ''[[Hard Promises (1991 film)|Hard Promises]]'' (1991) "only to work with Grant", although Grant was later replaced as its director.Jarboe, Jan. "Sissy Spacek's Long Walk Home", ''Texas Monthly'', February 1991, p. 126. In 1992, Grant played Dora Cohn, the mother of [[Roy Cohn]] in the biographical made-for-TV film ''[[Citizen Cohn]]'', which garnered her yet another Primetime Emmy Award nomination. ===2000s–present=== In 2001, Lee Grant portrayed Louise Bonner in [[David Lynch]]'s critically acclaimed ''[[Mullholland Drive (film)|Mullholland Drive]]''. From 2004 to 2007, [[Carlin Glynn]], [[Stephen Lang (actor)|Stephen Lang]], and Grant served as co-artistic directors for the [[Actors Studio]].Lipton, James. ''Inside Inside'', Penguin Group (USA), October 18, 2007; {{ISBN|9781101211991}}, pg. 112 In the early 2000s, Grant directed a series of ''[[Intimate Portrait (TV series)|Intimate Portrait]]'' episodes for Lifetime Television, that celebrated a diverse range of accomplished women. In 2013 she returned to the stage, after a nearly forty-year absence, to star in ''[[The Gin Game]]'', part of a benefit for improvement programs at the Island Music Guild. Grant played Fonsia Dorsey opposite [[Frank Buxton]] as Weller Martin; her daughter [[Dinah Manoff]] directed the production.{{cite web|url=http://www.kitsapsun.com/news/2013/aug/12/theater-high-powered-cast-deals-this-gin-game/?partner=RSS#axzz2xZu7fd3s|title=Theater: High-powered cast deals this 'Gin Game'|author=Michael C. While secondary and tertiary sources put Grant's year of birth between 1925 and 1931 she was almost certainly born in the mid-1920s. Public records indicate she was born in 1925 but a ship manifest and congressional testimony favor 1926. Recent interviews with Grant and her autobiography suggest 1927, although Grant herself is inconsistent on the subject.

18 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Jesse Ellis Lingard''' (born 15 December 1992) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]] or as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Jesse Lingard making the jump from promising youngster to great player|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/manchester-united/360/blog/post/3333117/jesse-lingard-making-the-jump-from-promising-youngster-to-great-player|publisher=ESPN|date=2 January 2018|accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Why Lingard has become a perfect 10|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fanzone/News-And-Blogs/2018/Jan/Why-Jesse-Lingard-has-become-the-perfect-no,-d-,10-at-Manchester-United.aspx|publisher=Manchester United F.C.|date=3 January 2018|accessdate=4 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103234630/http://www.manutd.com/en/Fanzone/News-And-Blogs/2018/Jan/Why-Jesse-Lingard-has-become-the-perfect-no,-d-,10-at-Manchester-United.aspx#|archive-date=3 January 2018|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> for {{English football updater|ManchesU}} club [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and the [[England national football team|England national team]].
Lingard made his senior debut while on loan at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 2012, and spent time on loan at [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] and [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] during the 2013–14 season and at [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in 2015.
He represented England at [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels, before making his senior international debut in October 2016 and went to represent his country at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], a tournament where England reached the semi finals-finishing fourth.
==Early life== Lingard was born in [[Warrington]], Cheshire,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/jesse-lingard-238970/ |title=Jesse Lingard |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> and attended [[William Beamont Community High School]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisischeshire.co.uk/news/2352570.jesses_england_chance/ |title=Jesse's England chance |first=Chris |last=Flanagan |website=This is Cheshire |publisher=Newsquest |date=20 June 2008 |accessdate=19 September 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054639/http://www.thisischeshire.co.uk/news/2352570.jesses_england_chance/ |archive-date=21 September 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Club career== ===Manchester United=== ====Youth career==== Lingard joined Manchester United's youth academy at the age of seven and progressed through the age groups.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/manchester-united/story/2705328/jesse-lingard-says-first-manchester-united-goal-a-dream |title=Jesse Lingard says first Manchester United goal a 'dream come true' |first=Richard |last=Jolly |publisher=ESPN FC |date=8 November 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> He was part of the Manchester United team that won the [[2010–11 FA Youth Cup]],<ref name=FAYC>{{cite web |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/The-Academy/Academy-News/2011/May/man-utd-v-sheff-utd-fayc-final-2nd-leg.aspx |title=FAYC: United 4 Sheff U 1 |first=Adam |last=Marshall |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103122714/http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/The-Academy/Academy-News/2011/May/man-utd-v-sheff-utd-fayc-final-2nd-leg.aspx |archive-date=3 January 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> before signing a professional contract in the summer of 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/~/media/Files/TheFAPortal/governance-docs/registrations/july-2011.ashx |title=List of Players under Written Contract Registered Between 01/07/2011 and 31/07/2011 |format=PDF |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref>
====2011–12 season==== Lingard was first included in a senior matchday squad on 30 November 2011, in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] quarter-finals against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at [[Old Trafford]], remaining unused as Sir [[Alex Ferguson]]'s team lost 2–1 after extra time.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sheringham |first=Sam |title=Manchester United 1–2 Crystal Palace |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/15850177 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He had his only other call-up of the season on 4 January 2012, again unused in a 3–0 away [[Premier League]] loss to [[Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Saj |title=Newcastle 3–0 Man Utd |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/16343415 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== [[File:Jesse Lingard (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|left|Lingard during the [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] pre-season friendlies in 2012]] On 6 November 2012, Lingard and teammate [[Michael Keane (footballer, born 1993)|Michael Keane]] joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on loan for a month.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/061112-city-squad-bolstered-by-united-loan-double-469523.aspx |title=City Bolstered By United Loan Double |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=6 November 2012 |accessdate=6 November 2012}}</ref> He made his competitive debut later that day, in a 0–0 [[EFL Championship|Championship]] draw away to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], coming on as a substitute for [[Martyn Waghorn]] in the 85th minute.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bolton 0–0 Leicester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20134517 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 November 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> His loan was later extended to 2 January 2013,<ref>{{cite web |first=Adam |last=Marshall |title=Reds trio extend loan deals |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2012/Dec/michael-keane-and-jesse-lingard-rejoin-leicester.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=5 December 2012 |accessdate=5 December 2012 }}</ref> and he totalled five appearances for the Foxes.
====2013–14 season==== Lingard was selected in the 19-man squad for Manchester United's 2013 pre-season tour.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/manchester-united-still-hopeful-darren-5066813 |title=Manchester United still hopeful of Darren Fletcher return |first=Stuart |last=Mathieson |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=11 July 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> He scored his first two goals for United in a 5–1 friendly win against the A-League All Stars in Sydney on 20 July,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/07/20/uk-soccer-united-australia-idUKBRE96J04H20130720 |title=United thrash Australia All Stars in friendly |first=Nick |last=Mulvenny |agency=Reuters |date=20 July 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> the first of which was the club's first goal under new manager [[David Moyes]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jul/20/manchester-united-aleague-all-stars-win |title=Manchester United thrash A-League All Stars to give David Moyes first win |first=Jamie |last=Jackson |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=20 July 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> After the match, he said "I believe in myself but I have to start believing in myself more".<ref name=TourQuotes>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/manchester-united-youngster-jesse-lingard-told-to-believe-in-himself-8725819.html |title=Manchester United youngster Jesse Lingard told to believe in himself |first=Simon |last=Stone |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=22 July 2013 |accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref> He also scored against [[Yokohama F. Marinos]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/286586/report |title=Yokohama F Marinos struck late to beat David Moyes' Manchester United 3–2 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=23 July 2013 |accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref> and [[Kitchee SC]] to finish the tour as top scorer with four goals in as many matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/lingard-seals-impressive-manchester-united-5380389 |title=Lingard seals impressive Manchester United victory over Hong Kong's Kitchee FC |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=29 July 2013 |accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref>
Although he had hoped to "skip the loan stage this time and break straight through" at Manchester United,<ref name=TourQuotes/> Lingard joined [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on a month's loan on 19 September,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24164296 |title=Jesse Lingard: Birmingham City sign Man Utd youngster on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 September 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> and went straight into the starting eleven for the Championship match against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] at [[St Andrew's (stadium)|St Andrew's]] two days later. He opened the scoring after 20 minutes with his first goal in senior football when goalkeeper [[Chris Kirkland]] parried [[Chris Burke (footballer)|Chris Burke]]'s shot, completed his [[hat-trick]] 13 minutes later, and scored a fourth in the second half to secure a 4–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24089685 |title=Birmingham 4–1 Sheffield Wed |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 September 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Lingard was unavailable for Birmingham's League Cup third-round tie because Manchester United did not want him [[cup-tied]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-boss-lee-clark-6083766 |title=Lee Clark: We want Jesse Lingard here for as long as possible |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=24 September 2013 |accessdate=18 October 2013}}</ref> then in his third league match, he made up for missing a penalty, awarded when he was fouled apparently outside the area, with an 89th-minute header to complete a 4–0 defeat of [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Ged |last=Scott |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24246482 |title=Birmingham City 4–0 Millwall |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Agreement was reached to extend Lingard's loan until 14 December,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24582877 |title=Jesse Lingard: Man Utd youngster to extend Birmingham City loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 October 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> but he then missed three matches while receiving treatment at Manchester United for a knee injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-jesse-lingard-set-6271456 |title=Jesse Lingard return set to boost Birmingham City |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=5 November 2013 |accessdate=10 November 2013}}</ref> The loan was further extended, to 1 January 2014,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25138529 |title=Man Utd's Jesse Lingard extends Birmingham City loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 November 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> but Lingard was suspended for the last two matches of the spell. Against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 26 December, he was sent off for a lunge on [[Jordi Gómez]] immediately after being refused a free kick when he appeared to be fouled.<ref name=Disappoint>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11694/9089639/sky-bet-championship-birmingham-boss-lee-clark-disappointed-with-jesse-lingard |title=Sky Bet Championship: Birmingham boss Lee Clark disappointed with Jesse Lingard |publisher=Sky Sports |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref>
Although Birmingham hoped to extend the loan,<ref name=Disappoint/> Lingard returned to Manchester United and was an unused substitute in the match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 11 January.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25600466 |title=Manchester United 2–0 Swansea City |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 January 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
On 27 February 2014, Lingard joined another Championship club, [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], on a 93-day loan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Albion sign Man United's Lingard |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/news/article/brighton-hove-albion-sign-manchester-united-striker-jesse-lingard-1385273.aspx |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=27 February 2014 |accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on 8 April, in a 4–1 win against former club Leicester City, who had sealed promotion to the Premier League days earlier.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leicester City 1–4 Brighton & Hove Albion |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26830309 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> While with Albion, Lingard played 17 times, including in the [[EFL Championship play-offs|Championship play-offs]], and scored 4 goals.<ref name=sb1314/>
====2014–15 season==== On 4 August 2014, Lingard came off the bench to score the third goal in United's 3–1 [[2014 International Champions Cup|International Champions Cup Final]] win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. He made his competitive debut for the club in the first match of the [[2014–15 Premier League]] season at home to Swansea City, starting the match but was replaced by [[Adnan Januzaj]] because of injury after 24 minutes. Swansea won 2–1 in [[Louis van Gaal]]'s first competitive match as United manager.<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Manchester United 1–2 Swansea City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28718345 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
On 2 February 2015, Lingard joined Championship club [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31104738 |title=Transfer deadline day: Thomas Ince & Jesse Lingard join Derby |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He made his first start on 14 February, against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-Jesse-Lingard-hopes-given-coach/story-26029439-detail/story.html |title=Derby County: Jesse Lingard hopes he has given coach plenty to think about |first=Chris |last=Watson |newspaper=Derby Telegraph |date=15 February 2015 |accessdate=17 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217131255/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-Jesse-Lingard-hopes-given-coach/story-26029439-detail/story.html |archivedate=17 February 2015 }}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== [[File:Cskamu 31.jpg|thumb|upright|Lingard playing for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in 2015]]
On 7 November 2015, Lingard scored his first senior goal for Manchester United in a 2–0 win against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at Old Trafford, opening the scoring with a shot past [[Boaz Myhill]] from outside the penalty area.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/07/manchester-united-west-bromwich-albion-premier-league-match-report |title=Manchester United far from pretty but Jesse Lingard sinks West Brom |first=Jamie |last=Jackson |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=8 November 2015 |accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref> On 12 January 2016, he scored against Newcastle United in a 3–3 draw at [[St James' Park]], with a finish that went between the legs of the goalkeeper after a reverse assist from [[Wayne Rooney]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Froggatt|first1=Mark|title=Newcastle United 3 Manchester United 3|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2016/Jan/match-report-newcastle-united-v-manchester-united-barclays-premier-league.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=12 January 2016 |accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref> He added his third goal of the season on 2 February against Stoke City in a 3–0 victory with a closer range diving header from a cross by [[Cameron Borthwick-Jackson]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Gemma|title=Manchester United 3 Stoke City 0|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2016/Feb/match-report-manchester-united-3-0-stoke-city-premier-league-2-february-2016.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=2 February 2016 |accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref> On 7 February 2016, Lingard scored his fourth goal of the season in a 1–1 draw against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], breaking the deadlock with a spin and shot inside the penalty area.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35453203 |title=Chelsea 1–1 Manchester United |first=Neil |last=Johnston |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 February 2016 |accessdate=3 August 2016}}.</ref> On 21 May 2016, Lingard scored the winning goal for Manchester United in the [[2016 FA Cup Final]] against Crystal Palace, having come on as a second-half substitute for other goalscorer [[Juan Mata]].<ref name=2016FAC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36292265 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2016 |accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== Lingard scored the opening goal as Manchester United beat Premier League champions Leicester City 2–1 to win the [[2016 FA Community Shield]].<ref name=2016FACS>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36934956 |title=Leicester City 1–2 Manchester United |first=Chris |last=Bevan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 August 2016 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> He scored another important goal in February 2017, this time United's second of a 3–2 win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in the [[2017 EFL Cup Final]].<ref name=2017EFLC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39018813 |title=Manchester United 3–2 Southampton |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date=26 February 2017 |accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref> On 6 April 2017, Lingard signed a new contract with Manchester United, of four years with an option for a fifth.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11667/10827468/jesse-lingard-agrees-new-four-year-deal-at-manchester-united |title=Manchester United confirm Jesse Lingard has signed new deal |publisher=Sky Sports |date=6 April 2017 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== {{expand section|date=December 2018}} [[File:Press Tren CSKA - MU (7).jpg|thumb|left|Lingard (right) with teammates [[Marcus Rashford|Rashford]] and [[Eric Bailly|Bailly]] before a [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] match in 2017]]
====2018–19 season==== {{expand section|date=December 2018}} On 5 December 2018, Jesse Lingard scored his first domestic goal of the season in a 2–2 draw against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11661/11572509/manchester-united-2-2-arsenal-spoils-shared-after-frantic-clash|title=Manchester United 2–2 Arsenal: Spoils shared after frantic clash|website=Sky Sports}}</ref> Two weeks later, in the [[Liverpool F.C.–Manchester United F.C. rivalry|North West derby]], Lingard scored his second of the season in a 3–1 loss to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/11583137/liverpool-3-1-manchester-united-xherdan-shaqiri-sends-liverpool-top-with-second-half-double|title=Liverpool 3–1 Manchester United: Xherdan Shaqiri sends Liverpool top with second-half double|website=Sky Sports}}</ref> During United's first game under new interim manager [[Ole Gunnar Solskjær]], Lingard doubled his season's tally, scoring a penalty and a goal from open play in United's 5–1 win over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], in addition to an assist for [[Anthony Martial]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.manutd.com/en/news/detail/match-report-cardiff-1-manchester-united-5-premier-league|title=Report: Cardiff City 1 Manchester United 5|website=www.manutd.com}}</ref> On 25 January 2019, Lingard scored the second goal in a 3–1 win over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the fourth round of the FA Cup.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/01/25/arsenal-vs-manchester-united-fa-cup-fourth-round-live-score/</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== Lingard played three times for [[England national under-17 football team|England at under-17 level]] in the 2008 Nordic Tournament.<ref name=FAprofile>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/All-Teams/Players/L/jesse-lingard |title=Jesse Lingard |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref> He received his first call-up for the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 team]] for the [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly match]] against [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland under-21s]] on 13 August 2013, and made his debut as a second-half substitute for [[Nathan Redmond]] as England won 6–0.<ref name=FAprofile/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23690472 |title=England Under-21s thrash Scotland 6–0 in friendly |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> On 21 June 2015, Lingard came off the bench to score the winner in a [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] group match against [[Sweden national under-21 football team|Sweden]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Brendan |last=McLoughlin |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33085670 |title=Sweden U21 0–1 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 June 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
===Senior=== [[File:Jesse Lingard 2018.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Lingard playing for [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]]
After [[Michael Carrick]] and [[Jamie Vardy]] withdrew through injury, Lingard received his first call-up to the [[England national football team|full England squad]], for a friendly against [[France national football team|France]] on 16 November 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34825726 |title=England v France: Jesse Lingard & Ryan Mason join squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 November 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He did not appear in the match.
Lingard received his next call-up for [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|World Cup qualifiers]] against [[Malta national football team|Malta]] and [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]] in October 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37530593 |title=Jesse Lingard: England call up Man Utd winger for World Cup qualifiers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 October 2016 |accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> He made his debut against Malta, starting on the left wing as England won 2–0.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/oct/08/england-malta-2-0-world-cup-qualifier-five-talking-points-waybe-rooney-jesse-lingard-roberto-mancini|title=England 2–0 Malta: Five talking points from Wembley|last=Fifield|first=Dominic|date=8 October 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=8 October 2016}}</ref> Lingard scored his first goal on 23 March 2018, in a 1–0 win over the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] in a friendly.<ref name=NetherlandsGoal>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43380175 |title=Netherlands 0–1 England |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 March 2018 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
[[File:FWC 2018 - Round of 16 - COL v ENG - Photo 067.jpg|thumb|upright|Lingard playing for [[England national football team|England]] against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] last 16]]
In May 2018, Lingard was named in the 23-man England squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref> On 24 June, Lingard scored his first ever [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] goal in a 6–1 victory over [[Panama national football team|Panama]] during their second group stage match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2018/06/24/england-panama-world-cup-goals-video-highlights-kane-rashford-sterling|title=WATCH: Kane Hat Trick, Stones, Lingard Pace England's Rout of Panama|publisher=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=24 June 2018}}</ref> During the tournament, Lingard received five starts, plus a substitute appearance in the third place play off against Belgium which saw England finish fourth in the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mykhel.com/football/fifa-world-cup-2018-england-jesse-lingard-p109322-tp114-l4/|title=Jesse Lingard FIFA World Cup 2018 Stats, Records, Position – myKhel|website=mykhelcom}}</ref>
During the November international break, Lingard scored the first goal in [[Wayne Rooney]]'s farewell match against the USA on 15 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45174412|title=England 3–0 USA|publisher=BBC|date=15 November 2018}}</ref> On the following Sunday, Lingard scored the equaliser in 2–1 win over Croatia which put England top of their group and qualified them for the [[UEFA Nation's League]] semi-finals to be held in June 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/nov/18/england-v-croatia-nations-league-live|title=England 2–1 Croatia: Nations League – as it happened|first=Rob|last=Smyth|date=18 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/11/18/england-vs-croatia-nations-league-live-score-updates/|title=Harry Kane gives England battling win over Croatia and Nations League qualification|first1=Jason|last1=Burt|first2=Alan|last2=Tyers|date=18 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>
==Media== Appearing in EA Sports' [[FIFA (video game series)|''FIFA'']] video game, two of Lingard's [[goal celebration]]s are featured in the series. His imaginary flute playing celebration appears in ''[[FIFA 18]]'',<ref>{{cite news |title=How to do the 12 new FIFA 18 celebrations – plus more of our favourites |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/how-do-12-new-fifa-18-celebrations-plus-more-our-favourites?page=0%2C1 |accessdate=11 October 2018 |work=FourFourTwo}}</ref> and the ‘Milly Rock’ dance celebration features in ''[[FIFA 19]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title=UPDATED FIFA 19 new celebrations and tutorial, ft Cristiano Ronaldo, Paul Pogba and Neymar |url=https://talksport.com/football/418292/fifa-19-new-celebrations-cristiano-ronaldo-paul-pogba-neymar |accessdate=11 October 2018 |agency=Talksport}}</ref>
==Personal life== Lingard was born in England, and his paternal grandparents are emigrants from [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/world-cup/2018/07/06/5b3f3e7cca47417e648b45fe.html|title=FIFA World Cup 2018: The children of immigrants who want to bring World Cup glory to England – MARCA in English|publisher=}}</ref> Lingard is a cousin of [[Everton L.F.C.|Everton]] and [[England women's national football team|England]] international footballer [[Gabrielle George]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43527545|title=England goalscorer Lingard takes on footballing cousin |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 March 2018|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref>
